text: The battle won, our general chases down the enemy general and challenges them to a duel. Everyone watches, rapt as the two leaders clash, each giving good account of their abilities. After an impressive bout that will be talked about for years, our general stands victorious.

Born in Fuchun County, you can trace your ancestry to the great Sun Tzu himself! You made a name for yourself as the scourge of pirates near and far. Considered reckless by some and brave by all, you have a duty to your family, brave southlanders all. Your two sons are the apple of your eye, but one day you hope for a daughter. Yet this land is wracked by war, and so you must fight so that peace may reign.

One of your generals falls behind during the retreat, making them a target for an enemy archer, who looses an arrow at them. \\n\\n However, the general catches the arrow, knocks it back into a bow and returns it, wounding the original sender with the easy flow of a musician plucking a harp.

A fire broke out in one of your settlements. Thinking quickly, your resourceful general calls over some villagers and orders them to form a chain from the nearby river to the village, filling kitchen pots and pans with water to put out the fire.

In nature, lies truth. The path to the enemy camp is strewn with decay; our scouts report a dead wolf on the trail. The enemy's supplies must be running short, and their attempts to forage must be failing. Soon, they must give up their fruitless assault!

It has begun! Across the lands, the banners of the Yellow Turbans are being raised, hastened by the defection of Tang Zhou.\\n\\nYou have sent out a call to arms to the empire, stretching the limits of your mandated powers as you send brother against brother. Your most loyal subjects hastily march to war, but the more ambitious warlords are disturbingly slow to react...

Lord Cao Cao - you have been cast out; branded an enemy of the empire! It is clear that only you have the capability to end Dong Zhuo's tyranny and bring peace. \\n\\n You can use the surging population and pliable peasantry of your homelands to your advantage, whilst vulnerable foes to the north may make expansion there beneficial. \\n\\n The time has come to increase your prestige and influence, then unite what has been divided!

Chaos grows, Liu Biao, and threats abound! Sun Ce and his vassals have raised arms against you. To complicate matters, there are also rebellions to the south; Huang Zu is doing what he can to fight them on your behalf. \\n\\n To the north, Cao Cao fights with Yuan Shao – a temporary reprieve, as whoever emerges victorious will surely turn upon you. Likewise, the Nanman are occupied with one another, but nearby Shi Xie eyes all surrounding lands with greed. \\n\\n You cannot over-extend yourself, Liu Biao. Deal with your immediate threats and consolidate, lest you be overwhelmed!

The Elder Qiao, a gentleman of the Han, has two daughters, famed throughout the lands for their beauty and musical skill. Out of respect for you and your prestige, he offers them to you and your sworn brother in marriage.

No matter how skilled the warrior and the leader, even they falter sometimes. You were captured by the enemy after a battle took a turn for the worst. You have been released this time, but the next time you charge the same foe, this error will not be made...

The work to ensure your heir is prepared for their future role is almost endless, and you labour tirelessly to ensure they live up to the demands your ambition makes of them. Today, you take a step closer towards that goal, as an aspiration task is now complete! Your heir will thank you when the time comes to inherit.
This administrator loses money in a business deal on some silk products. The deal was generous, and so a large deposit was put down, only for the silk to be stolen by bandits along the trade route.

It is easy to espouse kindness, but to act kindly requires scrutiny and stamina to go beyond your remit. On hearing a thief’s explanation that they stole only to provide for a helpless baby sibling, your administrator conducts a thorough investigation, proving their words and pardoning the offender.

Your attendant has met up with a confidant in the local province. Over tea, they discuss ways to further improve the local workshops. The insight has inspired your attendant to reach new heights with their exploitation of industry.

This administrator wanders into a military district and rounds up the garrison to work on local buildings in lieu of training. Though this will greatly help in the construction of the area, it means there is an exploitable gap in our defences.

You wake up feeling refreshed after a great night's sleep, not a care in the world. Until you hear that your general, Zhang He has surrendered to Cao Cao. There is silence, broken only by the crash of your cup, as it falls, from your hand, to the floor.

Two warriors are brought before you, bowing, one of them speaks. "Cousin, I am Xiahou Dun, and this is my brother Xiahou Yuan, long ago we played together as children. Now we are adults, in a world  of chaos. Allow us to use our blades in your service."

While moving through the land, something draws you to an old well. You peer over the edge, and see a faint glint from the bottom. As you pull the rope up, a familiar shape rises out of the darkness. It is a beautiful seal of jade - it is the seal of the emperor!

Overseeing a tiresome and long-standing quarrel between landowners, this administrator silently places a small blade on the table between them and gives each a hard stare. \\n\\n The landowners quickly come to a compromise, and the administrator’s intimidating reputation means less adjudicating over petty squabbles will be needed in future.
Your general believes that true courage is to ignore any warning of danger and plunge in regardless; a brave person challenges threats, but it is reckless to do so without assessing the consequences.

As king of the five valleys, Shamoke has gained the respect and fealty of many of the Nanman peoples, protecting them from the baleful influence of the Han, while at the same time remaining on good terms with the empire. By appeasing both sides, he plays a dangerous game, as any misstep could lead to abject disaster.

Luo Jun arrives and you greet each other warmly. "You have completed the tests and passed with flying colours. The land and the people sing your praises. Now, let us go and show the others how it's done!"

It is said by some that caution is true wisdom; patience in the face of danger. Some would disagree, but not these two, whose bond is forged from their shared beliefs. Hopefully they do not become overcautious together!

Regretfully, one of your prize horses dies. The blame lies with the bumbling incompetence of your administrator. Instead of signing an execution order for a convicted criminal, they sign it for the horse, and send a bemused criminal off to battle as the mount of an even more bemused rider!

Though war brings chaos and disharmony to China, there is glory to be gained in battle all the same. As warriors clash on the battlefield, the victorious cover themselves in glory. One particular warrior excels, a unique talent that you would do well to keep close.
To spy is simply to tilt the scales in the right direction. These warlords are petty and self-serving - I must convince them of my right to rule, even if I must use subterfuge to do so…
We accrue power in the  name of a righteous cause - I will use this newfound power and responsibility to continue to prosecute China's enemies!

A glorious day! All your rivals have either fallen to your blade or joined your ascendency – you are now the undisputed leader of the tribes of the south! Tonight we shall feast, celebrating the true unity of all Nanman peoples.

A general comes to you with our banner in their hands, saying it was found earlier this morning, fallen from its flagpole. They see this as a bad omen; that some dire tragedy awaits an important figure from our faction.

It has begun! Across the lands, your banners rise. Each person seeking a brighter future free from corruption. The emperor, roused, has dispatched all his armies against you. The people shall not be silenced, the Azure Sky is at an end.
The Yangtze, more than any nation, holds the flow between north and south. The one who controls the Yangtze, then, controls China.
Sometimes, the sons are indeed damned by the sins of the father…
Chen Deng sends a raiding party

You throw a lavish celebration to honour the marriage of a relative. As the evening draws on, people start discussing China's ills and how best to cure them. \\n\\n Noting the conversation has become heated, you defuse it with a light-hearted witticism. To prevent further unpleasantness, you propose a game of dilemmas, winning many rounds and impressing everyone. \\n\\n Many of the guests are powerful and influential people, and this one successful evening has opened more diplomatic options to you.
You demand tribute from those beneath you, and fearing your wrath, they capitulate.
The Lady Zhurong, ever stalwart and loyal, has sent a gift – a token of her bond. It is a noble and unexpected gesture – a surprise, no doubt, but a welcome one all the same.
Sometimes, fate intervenes in proceedings; a lucky shot from your army exposes a weakness in the enemy defences. Do not let this opportunity go to waste; attack this point at once!
Its name and greatness will echo throughout history: the Kingdom Of Wu.

Sometimes, it seems, a healthy rivalry can have prosperous results. You are told that two warriors, having formed a friendship and rivalry, are training in every spare moment in a bid to outdo one another. This can only be good for you.

The 'bandits' carried strange banners and each wore a yellow headscarf. A prisoner you captured claims that they were a group called the Yellow Turbans and were rising up against the supposedly corrupt Han. Spitting on the ground, the prisoner shouts "For the Yellow Sky!" and leaps at you, revealing a hidden blade. One of your officers reacts quickly and slices off his head.

Your general engages in a debate with an opponent whose arguments amuse the crowd with their colourful euphemisms and innuendos. However, wordplay relies on ambiguities; your general simply responds with an ugly, but undeniable insult, causing their opponent to retire! There is much laughter from the crowd...

Several bodies of drowned birds are found in the river one morning. One of our generals believes that things of the air found dead in the water is a sign of the changing of the sky; whether the omen is good or bad is unknown to them, only that some profound change is coming.

It seems your cause is seized by divine providence; a shot from your forces strikes true, falling amongst the enemy buildings and causing a collapse. The enemy defence doubtless suffers from this destruction!

You have started growing your strength, and your troops are resting from their exertions in your name. As you sit to dine, a messenger bursts in before kneeling before you and handing you a missive. \\n\\n "My Lord! The Yellow Turbans are attacking! They field a force ten-thousand strong!".\\n\\n Although you do not seek out war, you know that in times of chaos, one must bear arms against all evil.

Your officials witness smoke rising from one of your villages when visiting it for a routine inspection. Assisting the garrison there to kill a small group of men armed with flaming torches, they then ask where the attackers came from. \\n\\n The garrison commander explains that the rioters were in fact locals, protesting one of your recent decrees. As your star rises, the divide between ruler and subjects is unavoidable. You will have to monitor public order more closely.

You have nearly unified Jing province under your control, but China remains deeply divided. Thugs and ruffians control the emperor, and upstart warlords run rampant everywhere else. You have attempted to serve the Han with loyalty and respect, but can you remain a loyal subject in such tempestuous times? What will you do if the emperor remains compromised and the court embroiled in conflict? Perhaps the time has come for a more pro-active approach...

Wei Yan, prone as he is to disagreement, is arguing with another general over who is to lead the coming attack. Fortunately, the attack is two-pronged, so you assign each general to a force, declaring the winner of the argument to be whoever sees victory first. Early that morning, wreathed in mist, Wei Yan charges out, and sees victory before the noon sun is high.

You return for a third time to the cottage of Sleeping Dragon. This time he is at home, but asleep. Determined to speak to him, you patiently wait for him to rise. Though at first he refuses, you manage to persuade him of the importance of his counsel, and he agrees to help you.

Once again, Zhuge Liang and Wei Yan have descended into an argument over strategy. Despite Zhuge Liang's superior argument, Wei Yan insists that his riskier strategy will prevail. Many worry that, if Zhuge Liang were not around to keep him in check, then Wei Yan would cause untold trouble...

My Lord, terrible news has arrived from the capital. It seems that, during the commotion, your sons Liu Fan and Liu Dan have been cut down! We should have saved them when we had the chance, but now it is too late. May the grief and guilt you must feel propel you forward and strengthen your resolve to save China from the chaos that consumes it!

A mutual friend is recovering from a feast organised by this administrator. Lasting five days, its culinary opulence has seldom been seen outside of legendary Mount Penglai. Lavish as a palace feast and just as well attended, the administrator never left their seat and had a bottomless appetite!

Even here, far from the capital, chaos is spreading. Your lands are threatened by ambitious warlords, Yan Baihu, and their greed cannot go unpunished. Those who call the southlands home, and others around the land sympathetic to your cause, must now rally to defend a way of life in danger of vanishing forever!
An Oath in the Peach Garden
It is only right that I gain in stature - I am the defender of the empire, and protector of the emperor. In time, all will see this!

When two warriors, possessed of an amiable spirit, meet one another, it is inevitable that they will become firm friends. \\n\\n And just so, for there is much to discuss and share in matters of being virtuous and sympathetic, and sharing that goodness with your fellow man. \\n\\n Sickening, really.

You have marched your troops long and hard - at each village you have passed, you have made the humble request for supplies that you might continue your march. \\n\\n At this settlement, however, you find nothing but apologies - they cannot afford to feed you, and so you must march on, hungry and increasingly discontent...

As you walk through a local village, you see three men in the town square. They are tied to blocks and a headsman stands above them. Their crime was spreading graffiti, promoting the Yellow Turbans around the village. Things seem to be getting out of hands with these Yellow Turbans...

When ordered to leave the lands by a local official, your general simply answers with a laugh and orders the official imprisoned. Conviction regarding one’s own actions is to be encouraged, but not at the cost of exceeding rightful authority, lest chaos surely spread!
After completing their mission, your spy encounters an enemy general. A tense and brief conversation follows, but when they part ways the general remains unaware of your spy’s affiliation.
Your efforts for the Empire have not gone unnoticed. An official arrives, and gives you the seal of prefecture for Anxi county. You cannot wait to tell your brothers about this!
Following your recent success, the captain of the Northern Army has come to pledge his devotion to you. He brings with him the full might of the professional army he commands.

Your general gifts you a beautiful mirror; its reflection has the clarity of a river under sunlight, it rarely needs cleaning and, while in their possession, it has brought them much good luck. Even more, they say placed correctly, this mirror can focus Qi more purely than any other.
Lü Bu Flees to Liu Bei

A report has reached you that your attendant, whom you sent to seek talent, has been courting people near and far, ingratiating themselves with some and alienating others. With one whom they met, they formed a connection, and the two have become bonded by fate.
It seems Meng Huo has also seen an opportunity here. Hearing of your war against Ahuinan, he has joined and will fight alongside you.
No army can march on an empty stomach. By controlling Kuaji – the realm's breadbasket – they could march forever.

A local festival lights up the night in one of the tribal territories, and Lady Zhurong herself is spotted moving amongst the crowds of revellers. She moves and dances along with them, and takes time to pay tribute both to the people themselves, and the god of fire, Zhurong, from whom – it is said – the lady takes her own name.

Your arrogant general arranges a festival in celebration of themselves! Humiliatingly, they were the only attendant as the guest of honour. An uncommon moment of self-reflection made them question whether they have any true friends, so they send a gift of gold to gain favour with you.
This settlement will be a valuable tool in our continuing endeavours - it must thrive, the population must grow, that it might best serve our needs.
Yuan Shu Plots to Kill Liu Chong

Over tea, you tell your general of your dream of a jade bird. The general takes a long sip of their tea, places the cup down, and looks you in the eye. A vision of a jade bird is an auspicious prophecy, the jade indicating imperial matters and the bird a being that can traverse the gap between earth and heaven.
Shocking news, the young emperor has been seized by one who seeks only to use them as a mere puppet. This is an affront to the han!
After sending the supplies to the units, your spy is left with a surplus of goods. They sell the extra items to merchants and forward the profits to you, for the cause.

You are brought an item wrapped in cloth - a gift from one of the masters of your arsenal. Pulling away its drapery, you find yourself gazing upon a weapon of exquisite craftsmanship. Such an armament, clearly made by one of considerable skill, is an offering you would be foolish not to accept.
Our cities shall continue to rise! The splendour of the Han, and the old ways, shall shine across the land and remind the people of the strength of our institutions!
You have ordered your subject's execution, the supreme price for their failure and an example to all.
You have ordered this individual be banished from your court and from your lands, their ongoing presence being an affront to your rule.

Ma Teng, with the tyrant dead, the capital is in chaos! You made haste to protect the emperor, yet the treacherous Li Jue deceived you, and now your forces lie battered and broken. Already, your ally Han Sui points the finger of blame at you. Can you maintain your friendship in the face of such travails, or must he too face the axe for his treason?

Thunder, accompanied not by rain, but by snow, has shaken this general. In hushed tones, they explain that this is surely an omen of chaos - when even the natural order cannot be trusted, friends can turn into enemies, and enemies become friends.

The world is all but lost to chaos, King Mulu – it may be that only you have the power and resolve to re-find balance. The tribes are fractured; if we cannot unify then we are doomed. The Han – broken but mighty – lumbers on, each vassal warlord vying to prove their strength. The united tribes may repel them, but first, they [[b]]must[[/b]] be united.
The minister Wang Yun is plotting the overthrow of Dong Zhuo. No longer willing to suffer the tyrant, it is said that Dong Zhuo's adopted son has been manipulated into striking the killing blow.

Important news! It seems Cao Cao has struck at Yuan Shao's vulnerable supply lines and burnt his granaries to the ground. Now his forces, without food, are dwindling away. This surely spells the beginning of the end!

Several miners are arrested for stealing rice from another village’s stockpile. However, their families are known to the local authorities to be law-abiding and respectful, with no previous blights of banditry. \\n\\n When questioned, the culprits admit their guilt but explain they only committed the theft because the price of food has increased beyond their modest means. Clearly, the population has grown beyond self-sufficiency, and you will need to start taking an active hand in managing future food production.
When one elite simply won't do.

Any attempt to capture this spy is as doomed as trying to tie water with a rope. When being chased by enemy soldiers, your spy clears a wall in a single bound, then scampers up a nearby tree with the agility of a monkey, watching as the soldiers below search for them in vain.

According to rumours, it would seem that two of your officers are taking a rivalry to heart. The two are seen arguing over who has slain the most enemies. The discussion becomes heated and they eventually have to be physically separated!

Despite your efforts, there is much work yet to do, Shi Xie. Whilst Shanyue rebels clamour to the north, your borders are otherwise calm, yet your family's lands are vast, and the potential for trouble exists throughout them. \\n\\n The Nanman remain a danger, and will grow more threatening if they manage to finally unify. Likewise, Sun Ce to the east is known for his expansionism, and your lands are surely tempting to him. \\n\\n Build your strength and prepare – war is not a matter of if, but when!

Lady Zhurong, having re-ignited her inner flame, is descending upon her enemies with a fury unmatched. For the next several seasons, her strength in battle will be overwhelming. Once these seasons are done, however, her fire will gutter, and she will become vulnerable to counter-attacks.

One of our spies has an ingenious flair for sending coded messages. They have rigged a special flag system to communicate over long distances to other agents and have trained pigeons to carry messages far out of reach of our enemies and into our hands. Who can predict what they will come up with next?

Your army desperately need arrows as soon as possible. Zhuge Liang declares that he can get 100,000 or offer his head if he fails. \\n\\n He sends straw filled decoy boats towards the enemy, and they generously fire 100,000 arrows into them, arming your troops with the ammunition they need.

Honour should be practiced always, not only during the kind of epic battles that bring fame and recognition. This administrator shows true honour by chasing thieves who stole from an elderly woman, beating the culprits and returning the goods before soothing the woman’s distress with kind words.

Even the most defiant general loves the back-and-forth of a good argument. \\n\\n Perhaps that is how these two, defiant and standoffish to the last, became friends? They test, rebel against, and fight each other, but still return for drinks and laughter. \\n\\n There are many complicated, unknowable routes to friendship.
With this commandery under my control, I am as powerful as any of these other 'noble' warlords. Soon they shall know just HOW strong I am...

The anonymous, libellous letter penned by your spy has destroyed the reputation of its subject. In a delicious irony, the victim chooses the very author of their troubles as their confidant, recanting their woes as your spy nods solemnly.
I mourn for the loss of a skilled warrior, and a noble, loyal comrade to our cause. We must continue to fight in their name!

The reports of increased pirate activity in Gulf of Tonkin have spread among the coastal settlements. In such times of strife wicked men are emboldened, preying upon the weak with no regard for law or morality.

Your general draws your attention to a rock broken in two. The split looks fresh and the plane of the cut is smooth. Your general says this portends that some great power, believed to be invincible, is about to be torn asunder by some quirk of fate, rather than the hand of man.

By Imperial Decree, the court has seen fit to grant Cao Cao the county of Chen in recognition of his services to the Emperor. Many expect you to accept this news readily, you have known of Cao Cao deeds for some time, but perhaps you have other designs?
Kong Rong is Sent to Beihai
Great lords and masters of the land, brough to heel by one far more talented and capable.

Long has the Silk Road sustained the land, carrying goods to far-flung lands and bringing back riches. Yet raids and invasions have begun to sap ever-deeper into the profits, and so the Han have raised taxes to fund defences of their most valuable route. \\n\\n The people, as is to be expected, are not best pleased.

Lord Tao Qian - Dong Zhuo has seized the emperor, and now wields imperial power to his own tyrannical ends! \\n\\n The Han dynasty must be saved, even if you must take their lands back by force. First, we must defeat the nearby Yellow Turban insurgents, then find a place to build our strength. Nearby, Liu Bei and Kong Rong are Han loyalists who may offer us aid. \\n\\n The time to act, my lord, is now!
The Dragon of the Yuan Falls

As they flee, one of the ragged remnants of a defeated force turns and, in a last desperate attempt, takes aim with a lance, aiming straight at Lady Zhurong. Yet before he can reach the apex of his throw, his arm is seized by the swift stab of a dagger. He falls from his steed, crying out in pain. As Lady Zhurong retrieves her dagger from his body, she muses on the price this foolhardy warrior will fetch for his release.

The subject of a libellous letter is made aware of your spy's hand in its authoring. The poison pen's victim can be heard uttering unrepeatable obscenities and swearing to inflict physically impossible punishments upon your spy's person!

At your instruction, dark deeds take place under cover of night. Our agents, charged with deadly purpose, poison the enemy's water supply, and even now the toxins course through our foes' bodies. Disease begins to spread behind the walls. Soon, they must fall.

Gong Du - as the Han begins to destroy itself, your opportunity has finally come! The empire still has power, and we are few, so we must gather our strength before striking. To the west and south are lands we could use to consolidate, but be wary not to let the empire overwhelm you! \\n\\n When you are ready, there will be none who can stop our righteous attack - the yellow banner of war rises!
Your general tells of a bright star falling into the territory of our enemy late last night. They interpret this as a sure sign that our foe's dynasty will shortly fall…

The people are stricken by a most mysterious, hideous and contagious plague; their bodies swell and their flesh blackens. Before death takes them, convulsions and terrible pain racks them. \\n\\n The people, blighted by this sickness, blame the Han for inciting the vengeance of heaven.

News reaches you that Yuan Shao has finally succummed. Whether an enemy, or an ally, he was a man of great charisma and a loyal officer of the Han. With his dreams in tatters, his sons have taken it upon themselves to tear apart the corpse of his empire.

An official arrives, demanding to see you. When you're alone, he asks you for a 'payment' to not report you to the government and strip you of your titles.\\n\\nYour brother Zhang, who has been drowning his sorrows in a bottle, hears of this injustice, ties the official to a post and flogs him viciously.\\n\\nYou think it best if you resign your commission.

My lord, the numbers amongst your ranks led by loyal captains grow by the day! Your enlistment of well-trained retinues such as these will ensure your forces remain unquestionably strong in future conflicts and your lineage remains unshakeable. \\n\\n"[[i]]The control of a large force is the same principle as the control of a few men: it is merely a question of dividing up their numbers.[[/i]]" – Sun Tzu

The comfort of camp can leave the constant warrior bored and restless, so Wutugu leaves in the early hours of the morning. There is commotion in the camp when he returns late in the evening, mauled and limping, the hide of a great bear hanging about his shoulders. Was his foray brave or merely foolish? As impressive a feat as it may be, Wutugu is still just a mortal man. It may be some time before he recovers fully.

Your chambers are filled with incense sticks. In the centre of the room, your general kneels on the floor, reciting from prayer texts in a hushed whisper. When asked the meaning of all this, they say the lamps in the room were extinguished with a chill breeze, which they believe to be a phantom.
Terrible news from the capital! The schemings of the Eunuchs have come to a head and they have killed the general-in-chief, He Jin!
What they lack in familial warmth, they make up for with martial synergy.
A Steed to Rival the Ages

People are often joined by their shared beliefs - be they religion or, more broadly, superstition. \\n\\n It comes as no surprise, then, when two of your warriors become friends after discovering their shared superstitions. \\n\\n No matter how occult or unlikely, the pair of them avoid anything that might bring bad luck.

As you see two men becoming friends, you are acutely aware that they are thoroughly deceitful individuals. \\n\\n You wonder to yourself how they can possibly remain friends when all they do is lie, yet there seems to be nothing stopping their budding union. \\n\\n You doubt it can last, but you have been wrong before...
Defeat!? Bah! Nothing more than a setback. Every last one responsible for humiliating me will be paid back a hundred times over, I swear!
With this commandery claimed, all of China knows the Yuan name, and the prestige associated with it. Let us continue, that my name may be heard louder in every land!

The Wuguo people's army is the strongest military force among the Nanman tribes. Their armour, made from dried vines, is said to be harder than iron and apparently able to withstand even the strongest of blows. At the head of this militaristic people stands King Wutugu, a proud and strong warrior with few obvious peers.

You have fought with noble passion, He Yi, but the rebellion falters. You have gathered the remnants of the fight together – a mighty host, capable of continuing the cause. You are liked by few, and hated by many, so it would be wisest to smother the weakest of your foes swiftly, before larger warlords turn their eyes upon you. \\n\\n You are unprepared now, He Yi, but with decisive action you could stand and fight on!
Determined bulkwarks of the northern territories. Under no circumstances to be mistaken for the Warriors of the South.

King Mulu shuns the company of people, preferring instead to spend time with the wild beasts which roam the land, with whom he feels a natural affinity; like them, he is a survivor. Many of his fellow leaders find him aloof and distant, but clearly they underestimate his intelligence and guile.

A trusted advisor informs you of something suspicious in one of your settlements. The roads, bridges and buildings are in poor condition, while the governor parades in silk robes far costlier than he should be able to afford. \\n\\n It appears some believe they can fill their own purses with funds trusted to them for public services. These underhand individuals believe that you own so many territories, you will not notice. \\n\\n You may wish to inspect this rise of corruption to seek to curb it.

Your captains are proving their worth on the battlefield, my lord. With each successive victory they enable you to grow stronger whilst your enemies tremble and scurry away. Ride forth, with your captains by your side, and show all of China the armies they must face should they dare to oppose you! \\n\\n"[[i]]A victorious army, opposed to a routed one, is as a pound's weight placed on the scale against a single grain.[[/i]]" – Sun Tzu
Defeated, Lü Bu seeks sanctuary in the court of Liu Bei. He has been granted amnesty for now, but we shall see how long this clemency lasts...

Though it seldom lasts more than a few hours, the sun in its entirety is blocked out by the passing moon, casting the land into darkness. \\n\\n Such an event is so rare few can remember another. In their panic, they blame the Han for cursing them with this ill omen.

While establishing control in the newly-occupied town, one of your officials is set upon by a particularly burly local. The attacker is a bona fide warrior, but the targeted official is also an ex-soldier, aptly skilled in combat himself. \\n\\n After a spectacular duel, the assailant is eventually subdued and detained.

A lengthy investigation into corrupt officials leads your administrator to a small building on the edge of town. A guard outside refuses entry, but they have not come so far to give up, so respond by knocking the guard out with one blow. Inside, they discover an illicit gambling den!
You have mastered the art of defence, and so institute new policies, intending to pass on your expertise to your troops on how best to protect themselves.

Alcohol can reveal people’s hidden natures. Your general has a weakness for the grape, and when their tongue is properly lubricated, has difficulty controlling it. At a recent banquet, they besmirched your name and embarrassed the guests, only to claim no memory the following day and beg your forgiveness.

Your people want for spiritual succour – succour that is sorely lacking now. That is, at least, according to the words of a shaman who has presented himself to you and your court. He offers to be the salve that the people sorely need, and as such enters into your service.

Reports have reached you that Meng Huo has been seen amongst the local people, offering alms and his considerable personal strength to ease their burden. So impressive was he that he purportedly lifted a cart, which was bogged down in the mud, single-handed and with his bare hands! Is he man or divine?!

Huang Shao! It is clear that the Han have lost the Mandate of Heaven - civil war, corruption and tyranny plague a once proud empire; we must seek to be the salve of the people's woes, and must be prepared to fight if we wish for peace. \\n\\n Start in the southeast, taking valuable territory to use as a base then, when you are ready, march to reclaim the Mandate and lead China back to peace!

The greatest warrior of the Mang and the greatest warrior of the Han; it is a tale likely to be woven through the threads of history long after all involved are just memories, thinner than dust on the wind. Their might is legendary, but who would win should they meet? Well, that has at last been decided...
Imperial Favour: A Gift from the Emperor

This administrator has passed a governmental test with full marks. Each question was answered fully; the tangles of complex official matters were solved as easily as picking a flower. They have more than proved their intelligence and fitness for the role.

The passage of the seasons, the blessings bestowed by the heavens, the trying times of hardship; all come and go. The Han endures, as it always has, as it forever will. You are leader of many, appointed by divine right. But human desires are not always noble – there are those who covet that which is rightfully yours, both within the empire and without.

You awaken from a tumultuous dream. In it, you experience death over and over, in myriad ways. The more you run from it, the more intensely it comes for you. Could this be a sign of a sealed fate? In which case, should you rebel against it?
As we advance higher amongst our companions, we should always remain committed to improving the institutions of the Han, so that our government improves all people's lives, not just our own!

You chose to heed Yuan Shao's advice, but it would seem he has betrayed your trust! You have learned that, whilst you were unsuspecting, he used the threat of force to confederate Han Fu! This betrayal cannot go unpunished, and you will make sure they regret their treasonous decision.

Sometimes a river, at an impasse, will split in twain. For weeks, vicious rumours have been circulating about the court around one of your hitherto loyal officers – of their treacherous disloyalty to you, and worse, their villainous thievery of your property! Looking deeper into the matter, your agents inform you that these rumours, whilst apparently untrue, were likely started by an enemy minister. Sadly, however, the damage to their reputation has already been done...

Liu Yan, my lord, you have been appointed as governor of Yi province as you requested. This place is far enough away from central Han rule that we can work on developing our ambition and aspirations for, dare I say it, emperorship! \\n\\nAs the Han Empire wavers under pressure from its foes, and the tyrant Dong Zhuo makes a mockery of the imperial authority, what opportunities will we carve out from this?

In the south there are rumours that a leader has risen among the tribes there, one who has united them all under a single banner. Whether they are a threat to the Han and the people of China is yet undecided; perhaps we should send emissaries to judge the worth of this new, burgeoning nation?

Having successfully bided your time, waiting and preparing for this moment, now you are ready. Your supplies are plentiful, your men poised for coming battle, and your own skills have been honed and sharpened to a razor's edge. Soon all of China will bow in obedience to you.\\n\\n To activate Wild Fire for this season, press the Wild Fire button, next to the Goddess of Fire icon on the Faction panel.

The Black Mountains are your home, Zhang Yan, but change is come to China - and with it, opportunity. You and your bandits have long worked both with and against the Han, but now you must work solely for yourselves. Use your networks, and your own power, to see your ambitions realised!

It is the nature of lesser man that they will envy their superiors. A rival of yours is overheard slandering your battlefield prowess to other soldiers. They claim they are clearly more adept than you and will prove it utterly in the next battle you share!

You are Liu Chong, a scion of the imperial line. Having narrowly avoided the headsman for the improper worship of Huang-lao, you seek to prove your virtue to the emperor. You are a master warrior and statesman, seeking to fan the flickering flames of the Han Dynasty. Your close friend and colleague, Luo Jun, has promised to aid you in your quest.

Cao Cao must be brought to justice. No longer shall he hold the emperor as a hostage! He is nothing more than the tyrants before him, and will be brought low. You have strong forces, powerful allies and a large estate- there is nothing, no one, who can challenge you now...

While executing an education programme in the local schools, your attendant enlisted the help of their friend, stationed nearby, to teach the peasantry. Their expertise has been invaluable and has improved the outlook for these people.

The heavy iron door bar lies on the ground, as does the previous contestant who tried to lift it. With a gruff snort, one of your officers steps forward. "Move aside, this is how it is done in my hometown!" \\n\\n With that, the officer takes one end of the bar and with a grunt, lifts it off the floor by just one end. The crowd goes wild!
My lord, Zhang Yan has left our faction. Reports are that he's returned to his old ways, and is terrorizing the Black Mountains in the North.
Lü Bu arrives at your palace. Though untested, his reputation is fearsome indeed. He has grown tired of his weak former master, and instead pledges himself to you.
The local gentry are thankful for your swift judgment; justice must be applied equally and without exception, if balance is to be maintained.

A cart arrives in your capital, filled with various goods from across the land. Among the myriad items is a gift from one of your talented armourers – a resplendent suit with a short, inspiring note attached from its maker saying "Only through strength and unity may the land be made whole."

As the rains fail to fall, so too does the land fail to produce. Soil hardens and dries, and crops diminish as nature starves. \\n\\n The people, following the land, suffer as the famine rolls across it. Many cannot help but interpret this as a sign of heaven's displeasure with the Han...

News reaches you of brigands descending into Han territory from the north. They will soon reach the Yellow River. With much of the land descending into chaos, such reckless violence is becoming alarmingly common.

Although fire burns, it can also fuse things together. \\n\\n So it is with these warriors, fierce of temperament and strong of will; they find friendship in one another, even if their dispositions will lead them into arguments of passion more often than not.

While travelling through hostile territory, our general is ambushed by bandits. To the brigands’ surprise, the general reacts with the agility of a deer, leaping high and clear of danger, then bringing their sword down as they descend, killing the closest thief and scattering the others.

Day becomes night, and then day once again. With every passing of the moon, more of our men fall to illness and disease. A local leader - a civilian - approaches you. The people are ready, they say, and although untrained, will fight in defence of their homes. It is a desperate move, but options are running out...

During the to and fro of war, you manage to capture an enemy officer. Though he fought bravely, he is no fool. He offers himself to your service - you have bested him, and by extension his master. \\n\\n Your strength is greater, and cause therefore just. He is your man now; he will fight for you.

You are knocked down in battle. You see a flash of metal, and close your eyes, but the blow never comes. \\n\\n You look up to see the brave and loyal Dian Wei, with the weapon meant for you embedded in his chest. He smiles and says "Live well, my lord, and fulfil your ambitions," before falling to the floor, dead.

Kindred souls are born of many virtues and vices. These two, understanding one another's craven inclinations, are unified through this shared belief. Although they are unlikely to topple any forts together, there is some comfort in knowing theirs is a friendship built on solid foundations.

War is declared! No longer will Meng Huo sit silently and endure belittlement from those who claim to rule over him. He has launched an open rebellion, and will have either freedom or death as his prize!
When the people speak your name, they do so with a smile. They benefit under your wise and generous rule, and there is happiness all across your faction.

You receive a commendation regarding the great shaman, Mulu. While supporting your troops on campaign, he is said to have led them along hidden paths, imperceptible to most, which drastically increased the speed of their advance – itself an advantage over the machinations of such an untrustworthy foe.
With this increase in rank, China comes another step closer to breaking the chains of tyranny - chains that will be broken by me! I must keep pushing onwards!
Allies are ever-welcome, if not well-mannered! Each friend that joins our cause knows it to be righteous and our enemies to be cretins - long may our kinship be strong!

Xiahou Dun’s eye is pierced by a stray arrow in battle. He pulls it out, plucking the eye from the socket with it. \\n\\n "Essence of my father, blood of my mother, I cannot throw this away!" he cries, then puts the eye into his mouth and swallows it!

Your attendant, while stimulating local markets, turns out to be a friend of one of the magnates in the region. Using this to their advantage, they report that they've secured greater investment in local commerce.

A messenger approaches, trailed by a wagon full of good. He kneels humbly before you. \\n"A gift from Gongsun Kang. With the fall of the Yuan, many loyal to their banner fled north into our lands. As a gift, my lord sends the heads of your enemy to show his loyalty to you."

Despite the chaos engulfing China, you have remained restrained, refusing to make your own appointments to vacant positions. The court is greatly pleased, and has granted you the title of General Who Pacifies the South - a great honour that will only enhance your legitimacy.

It is the nature of some to be inquisitive, yet it is others' nature to refuse to answer. \\n\\n The enigmatic tire of the ever-curious, and retreat. You are relieved, then, to see two of your more mysterious followers find friendship in one another. They ask no questions, and are perfectly content in that.

Your bowmakers toil day in and day out, supplying your army. On this occasion, a bow of considerable quality is produced, such that the maker responsible now comes bearing said item to you, as a gift.

This spy is like a shadow, leaving only a vague impression of themselves during missions. Challenged by an enemy officer, they give their name and explanations, and are excused. However, afterwards the officer struggles to remember their name, features and even the details of their conversation.

As a healer to the poorest folk of the land, you have seen the harshness of the Han government first hand. But no longer can you sit idly by; you have risen up with your brothers and the people have followed. The Han shall fall and the Way of Peace shall rise!

A loyal friend is as the mountains: unwavering before any adversity. \\n\\n Find a friend whose loyalty you never need question and you will never worry. You see a kinship forming between two that you know to be stalwart and true, and are heartened by it.

A cart arrives in your capital, filled with various goods from across the land. Among the myriad items is a gift from one of your talented armourers – a resplendent suit with a short, inspiring note attached from its maker saying "Only through strength and unity may the land be made whole."

Squatting among the destroyed remnants of Luoyang, the emperor and his court found themselves in dire circumstances. Lacking supplies, they are reduced to eating roots from the earth. \\n\\nThe court looks to a protector. The Yuan believe themselves the only suitable candidates for the task, and have taken the emperor under their proud wings.

The two heaven-joined lovers, Meng Huo and Zhurong, have joined their power in marriage. By so doing, their tribes too have entwined – they now present a united front against any who would oppose them!
The political hostage has safely arrived in our lands. They have been housed within our capital and await your orders.\\n\\nLet us hope that this will bring our unruly vassal to heel.

The master animal trainer from one of your commanderies gifts you a most beautiful horse. "This is a rare specimen that wasn't easy to break in," he claims, "but such is the way with the greatest steeds. This magnificent beast is clearly fit only for one of high station with the utmost courage."

King Mulu has called his warriors together and blessed them for the struggle ahead. Not often one to aid his fellow man, preferring the purity of wild animals, this has been considered a good omen by his soldiers, who will now surely fight with even greater fervour in their king's name.

A rivalry can be healthy as a platform for two warriors to better themselves. If it is allowed to sour into bitterness and resentment, then issues will arise. Two of your officers are becoming heated with one another, and it is affecting their performance. Perhaps you should investigate?

Kong Rong visits your court and, citing his gratitude for your help against Yuan Shao, promises a reward! His talents as an administrator are well-known, and he declares he will bring these talents to bear in your employ.
Treason is the highest offence! If I ever encounter this cur again they shall face military justice! My trust should perhaps not be so easily given…

They say, in hushed tones, that you received the Books of Great Peace from the spirits of the south, and through study you have learned to control the elements themselves! Whatever spurious basis there is to these rumours, it clearly inspires your followers and strikes fear into your enemies!

Meng Huo, long has your family lived and thrived in the south. Far from the imperial capital the Southern Tribes, the Nanman, have been left to their own devices. Conflict between tribes, for land or prestige, has not been uncommon, but now it is time for a leader to unite the tribes under a single banner. You are that leader. Rise, Meng Huo, and carve a land from the swamps and jungles of the South.
With this commandery under our control, we can bring order to the chaos, and discipline to the populace. And from there, victory!

Meng Huo, having seen victory after victory, is becoming complacent. He believes himself now to be beyond reproach, and so has grown inefficient and lazy. Lady Zhurong, however, will brook no such lassitude, scolding her husband most severely for his lax attitude. She implores him, and he listens, regaining his ambition and passion for the cause.
The emperor's power wanes, whilst mine waxes! As I rise through the ranks, my light shines ever brighter. Soon, they will all see it is the only light they need!

Guan Yu is wounded. The legendary physician, Hua Tuo, arrives and offers to help heal his arm. However, when offered anaesthetic, Guan Yu refuses so he can continue to play Go while being healed at the same time!

Your attendant sent a recommendation about one of your generals, who took time out of their busy schedule to come and help organise the guerrilla forces in the area. With the two of them working together, the task proved much more successful!

You sit at the border between north and south, but are of neither. You have fought your way to power through guile and skill at arms, bringing both Nanman and Han to heel where they oppose you. A power vacuum grows, and you must be ready to fill it, but you must act swiftly, or others shall assume the mantle which is rightfully yours.

It is most common that greed, when manifested, makes for a selfish display. \\n\\n Yet somehow - seemingly in spite of all logic - two of your entourage find friendship in one another, even though their days are consumed by avarice. \\n\\n Whilst you cannot speak to their vices, you hope their rapport continues.

Your spy gains the confidence of an enemy general and begins to poison their mind against their own warlord. Branches of lies are supported by known truths, so the general cannot argue with the logic and must conclude that, in this instance, their loyalty is misplaced.
Villains to a man, but they do it with such impeccable panache.

You are drawn to a commotion outside as a group of warriors, flamboyantly dressed, ride into view. A fiery fellow steps forwards and announces that they are Gan Ning, a former pirate, who now seeks a worthy lord who will bring him riches and success.

Your plans are being thwarted by the upstart Ding Yuan. While others have bent the knee, he continues to defy you. But his forces are strong and his adopted son, Lü Bu, is said to be a fearsome warrior. You must therefore bide your time…

While replenishing supplies at your command, your attendant reports terrible news. It seems that some of the supplies gathered were infested and have spoiled! They have vowed to work even harder to rectify this mistake!
My bandits must know comfort and my enemies must know fear! This accomplishes both - I saw this opportunity, and I took it!

Squatting among the ruined remnants of Luoyang, the emperor and his court find themselves in dire circumstances. Lacking supplies, they are reduced to eating roots from the earth. \\n\\nThe court looks to a protector, and the Cao have answered the call. The emperor now falls under their dubious wings.
Scouts reporting gatherings outside your lands...

It is known that friendship is not only a matter of dependable allies, but also a companion that will spur you on. Two competitive warriors in your army develop a friendship, based on mutual betterment, each vowing to be greater than the other; they compete over everything, even eating!

Modesty is a noble trait to possess - even in the face of overwhelming praise the modest warrior remains demure. \\n\\n Two of your comrades, humble to a fault, find friendship in one another. \\n\\n The last you heard they were stuck in a doorway, insisting that the other go through first. [[b]]Insisting.[[/b]]

People are drawn together for many reasons. The love of art, the joy of war or - as in this case - a shared delight in cruelty. They spend much time together, discussing and - in some cases - enacting their twisted plots. \\n\\n You cannot condone their barbarism, but you're happy they have a friend in each other, you suppose.

Assassins have made an attempt not just on your life, but also that of your closest advisor, Luo Jun. Thankfully you were able to fight them off, but not before learning their source: Yuan Shu, the vile cur!
Kong Rong fought as well as he was able, but ultimately Yuan Shao's power was overwhelming, forcing the proficient governor to yield. Yuan Shao gifts his newly-conquered lands to his son, Yuan Tan.

The more brash amongst your generals and cohorts will often seek out others to validate their own daring behaviour. \\n\\n You hear of two such individuals, joined by their proclivity for ill-advised and reckless endeavours; they spur one another on to greater and greater acts of foolhardiness.
Returning to Sun Jian's first seat of power is like coming back to one's true home.
They can crush our bodies but they cannot overcome our spirit. Although we fall back now, we will return stronger, and they will know our strength!
An unexpected envoy arrived at your gates today - the very emperor himself. Not happy with his former regent, he fled captivity and sought your court instead. Now his fate lies in your hands...

What madness!? Our enemies make a brazen move and burst the dam! The bloated autumn waters beyond pour down onto our lands. Although our foes cannot avoid the indiscriminate flood either, our lands are grievously damaged.

Life is never simple, and at times we all tested in challenging, sometimes painful ways. Yet this general has difficulty choosing which grain of rice to eat first! Arriving at a fork in the road, your general’s soldiers are forced to wait for three hours while their leader's indecision paralyses them.

You read a report about one of your generals who beat six enemies single-handedly, largely due to the courage, speed and loyalty of their horse. \\n\\n Heroes have always had something – or someone - to help them achieve their rightful destiny. It can be a loyal follower, a trusted steed, a book of wisdom or a weapon of unique properties, but they all fulfil the same role. \\n\\n Whether it is fate, or by your very own will and actions, such a thing has come into your possession. The real test is figuring out how best to make use of it – or them – to help you achieve your goal.

In light of your co-operation towards mutual goals, the envoy returns, with gifts and a formalised treaty between your two factions. May this man's skills help strengthen our future relationship, and serve you well.

Mangyachang is known to be as fierce as an Ox, and twice as stubborn – they say he can crush mountain rocks with nothing but his bare hands. As such, he is forever questing for ever-greater tests of his power.
There is no telling where insurgency hides now - every warlord thinks themselves an emperor now - I reclaim this city in the name of the Han!

My lord, as promised, the deed is done. \\n\\n Smoke curls over buildings now reduced to ashes in the city; war is an ugly affair and innocence its first casualty. Once unleashed, fire is an indiscriminate killer, and many perished in the blaze. \\n\\n It will be some time until this city and its people recover.

As you approach the settlement, you hear a loud cheer from within. As you look on with confusion, your follower rides out towards you. "Great Teacher, the people have long awaited your guidance. We have kicked out the corrupt Han governor and we now seek to follow you!"
Messages have reached you that the warlord Yuan Shu has declared himself the emperor under heaven. Such a brazen act has angered many, but he has also drawn powerful nobles to his cause.
These crumbling walls are a metaphor for the Han - outdated and collapsing. Soon, they too will fall, and we will rise!

You are brought an item wrapped in cloth - a gift from one of the masters of your arsenal. Pulling away its drapery, you find yourself gazing upon a weapon of exquisite craftsmanship. Such an armament, clearly made by one of considerable skill, is an offering you would be foolish not to accept.
With this settlement claimed, we are one step towards reclaiming our land for our glorious cause - the loyal rebels, with my leadership, will see victory!
Stalwart and proud warriors of the southlands. Absolutely never to be confused with the Northern Defenders.

This general appears to be oblivious to the consequences of their actions. While in enemy territory, they went off hunting alone in the woods, only to get lost. Their calls for help were heard by enemy troops, and only the cunning of the general’s troops saved them from a quick – some may say deserving – death.

Sincerity, like honesty, is one of the most valuable facets of friendship. \\n\\n Two sincere souls come together, treating each other with honesty and respect - you expect, and hope, that a true, enduring kinship will be formed.
It was never my aim or intention to rise through the ranks - but I humbly accept this position, as it may help me to better soothe the suffering of the people.

Lord Liu Zhang, it has been a few years since your father's passing, and during that time China has only sunken deeper into turmoil and chaos. Amidst the storm, you have slowly consolidated your power to become ever stronger. \\n\\n The time is now! To set sights on your father's ambition, and achieve what even the great Liu Yan could not: to become the emperor of all China!

Your warrior-king, Meng Huo, is famed throughout the lands for his lavish banquets. His natural gift for hospitality has won many surprising candidates over to his side, and he continues to impress, both friend and rival alike, with his unsparing generosity.

There is a problem with two of your men. A good-natured rivalry has soured into nastiness and bitter feuding. At every turn, they scrap; be it verbally or physically. They even refuse to eat together. For now, this is holding, but at some point you may wish to intervene.

The tribes of Jiangyang are well known for their skill in fostering the land for the good of all. As a result, the wide expanses of their home territory have been given over to agriculture, with myriad fields growing all sorts of delicious, fresh produce.
With this settlement's liberation, the people here are freed from oppression! It is a small start, but significant. All of China must know this same freedom!

You have suffered setbacks in the past years, Zheng Jiang. That fool Zhang Yan overextended himself and attracted the wrath of Yuan Shao, who even now seeks to purge the bandits from the northern mountains, forcing you to head south in search of a more secure base.\\n\\nFirst you will need to find a new stronghold – supplanting the local bandit chief, Zang Ba, should give you that. Once you are secure, exploit the chaos engulfing the central plains to plunder, pillage, and build your legend!
The Dragon of the Yuan Falls

Due to their very nature, the truly humble are rarely spoken of. The work this court noble produces proves they derive satisfaction from the diligent completion of their responsibilities, rather than seeking recognition from their peers.

Seeing a blissful smile on your general's face, you ask them what great fortune has caused their happiness. They explain that their astrological signs are in alignment, a sign that their bad luck is soon to end, and harmony is within reach.

This will be the seventh time that Meng Huo has allowed himself to be captured, and he is as painfully aware of that fact as you are. The tribal leader now knows that he is beaten, and grudgingly pays respect to your superior strength. He offers himself in service to your confederation, joining his tenacity to yours.

You spy tries to sneak away under the cover of night, but is spotted climbing over a wall by an administrator cursed with insomnia, who alerts the guards. Although the spy manages to escape, their identity has now been revealed to all.
Your shrewdness in all matters of trade has created much prosperity for the people of Dong Wu. Its merchants present you with a gift to show their gratitude.
This victory is the first of many! I will prove my worth as everyone else falters - the coalition cannot stop the chaos, but I will show them that I can!

As you look out over your territory, you notice billowing black smoke rising to the heavens – the forest is ablaze, and the wildfire is spreading rapidly! It seems an enemy warrior, in a decisive yet reckless move, has set light to the nearby woods, and the prevailing winds have done the rest, causing a raging forest fire to take hold. Your aides report that unfortunately the fire has reached your nearby settlement, severely damaging the buildings there and killing some of the population.

Culture and learning form the backbone of any civilised society; China is no different. Through careful study, we attain greatness. \\n\\n Two of your more scholarly subordinates become firm friends, and while away the hours surrounded by scrolls and careful, intelligent conversation.

The inevitable has happened, as you always knew it would. Your one-time ally, Yuan Shao, has declared you a tyrant and raised his forces against your own. Unfortunately, in the field you are outnumbered, vital supplies are running low and you are now surrounded by enemies, all looking to topple your power. However, you know this land, better than any of them, and if you are able to restrict the fight to your home territory, with superior tactics and good advice, you will surely prevail.

If two people can be united by the desire to do good, then so too can they be united by the desire to do harm. \\n\\n Vengeance, dark and brutal, is what ties these two warriors together. \\n\\n Though their friendship may not last beyond bloody vengeance, they are serving, all the same, to strengthen one another, which can only be good.

One of your newest recruits has shown great promise, performing beyond expectations. Thus, he has been granted command as a general. This warrior - Wei Yan - promises to shine brightly with the promise of a glorious future.

There is wisdom in aligning with the powerful; those who stand alone soon find themselves at other's mercy. Your victory in war has seen nations fall, prostrate, in new-found loyalty to your name. \\n\\n A freshly-made vassal sends one of their own as a hostage - a dedication, they say, to their new master.
Concerning news arrives from the Western territories of the Empire. Some groups of auxiliaries, sensing an opportunity, have rebelled against the Han and begun terrorising nearby counties.

It is the time of the Harvest Moon, and the farmers of the local village are celebrating the fine harvest. They sit around the fire recounting the tale of Hou Yi and Chang'e, in which they were separated after she drank the elixir of immortality and took up residence on the moon itself!

There are those whose raw presence puts others ill at ease. Such creatures are usually solitary, as their intimidating nature isolates them. \\n\\n Despite this, two of your more divisive companions find friendship, presumably staring each other down until reaching some sort of silent understanding!

Though the tyrant is dead, control of the emperor is far from settled. Li Jue and Guo Si, two of Dong Zhuo's former generals and erstwhile allies, are the ostensible regents - but two such ambitious men could not work together for long. Mutual suspicion has escalated to paranoia, then hostility, and now gangs of their supporters skirmish in the streets and alleys of Chang'an.

Despite a praiseworthy effort to improve relations, your spy’s hated rival detracts from their efforts by implying they are of a mercurial and untrustworthy character; this spiteful action will only deepen the animosity between them.
Of all the treason that infects the land, this betrayal is the worst. I shall hunt down this turncoat slime and enact final justice myself!

The master animal trainer from one of your commanderies gifts you a most beautiful horse. "This is a rare specimen that wasn't easy to break in," he claims, "but such is the way with the greatest steeds. This magnificent beast is clearly fit only for one of high station with the utmost courage."

Zhang Yan, your isolation has left you bereft of allies, and your notoriety as King of the Black Mountain has painted a large target on your back. \\n\\n Backed into a corner, enemies close in on you from every direction. With Yuan Shao bearing down on you from the east, and Gao Gan pressing from the west, the situation is dire and your options are decidedly limited. \\n\\n Cao Cao may be your only chance to gain a powerful ally, and with Yuan Shao as a common foe, you might have chance to earn his favour. Yet if the heady sway of ambition calls, there is opportunity to be seized. The war between Cao Cao and Yuan Shao distracts them both, providing you chance to boldly steal their land from beneath them. A perilous risk for one in such a precarious position, but the greatest risks often yield the greatest rewards.\\n\\n Ultimately, the path forward is yours alone to decide; the fate of your people depends on you choosing wisely.

Your general brings you several fine oranges, juicier and sweeter than any others you have tasted. When you ask where these luscious fruits were grown, they tell you of an orchard on the edges of your commandery where the soil is rich; an omen that heaven approves of your rule!

The venerable Tao Qian lies on his deathbed. With no heirs to succeed him, he requests that you - a most honourable man in his estimation - assume his mantle. \\n\\n Despite your humble protestations, you know it would be most dishonourable to deny his final wish. As such, you inherit his lands and titles.

Being filial and incorruptible is a requirement for high office. This can, however, be taken too far, and if you write disapproving letters about the emperor, correct or not,  you should expect consequences.

As you examine your festering wound, your attendants bring a man in to see you. He is old but tall, with bright eyes and large ears. "This is the great healer, Hua Tuo", they say. "He has kindly offered to restore your wounds".

I have good news, my lord. \\n\\n Negotiations with the pirates were successful. Men who have no master but follow coin are surprisingly direct and reliable when paid in advance. \\n\\n They have dispatched ships and will proceed to harass the ports in the area. Their actions will divert valuable resources away from those local lords who have not yet offered us alliance or subservience.

The work to ensure your heir is prepared for their future role is almost endless, and you labour tirelessly to ensure they live up to the demands your ambition makes of them. Today, you take a step closer towards that goal, as an aspiration task is now complete! Your heir will thank you when the time comes to inherit.

Lord Liu Biao - you have been an effective governor, but even your territory is not safe from the rising chaos. Dong Zhuo controls your kin, the emperor, and it is not unthinkable that he will seek to eventually supplant him. \\n\\n You must ensure the Han dynasty survives, yet the ambitious lurk everywhere; Sun Jian and Yuan Shu have long coveted your territory, so you must tend to your own defences before looking to the rest of China's woes...
The Emperor, Liu Hong, is dead. It appears he has perished of natural causes, but his death has caused chaos across the lands.

A figure arrives at your camp – an advisor, they claim, to the enemy – wishing to defect. They claim to know the location of a crucial supply cache. Your advisors believe it to be a trap, yet Xun You speaks out in his defence. You should trust him, he says, and on your advice you deploy a force to investigate and secure this supposed cache.

You inspect the damage caused by last night’s heavy storm. Despite its rage, the only significant loss is a large and ancient pine tree, ripped from the ground so its roots jut upwards. One of your generals whispers that it is a sign that a long-powerful faction is nearing its end.

The captain of the guard informs you of angry peasants rioting in the capital. Incensed by the public humiliation and brutal execution of a peasant family, at the behest of a noble, they are holding the administration responsible for this injustice. The garrison has restored order but the damage has been done.

Your brother, Sun Quan, foolishly erected his camp without establishing the proper sentries. As such, in the middle of the night, a force of bandits swarms from the darkness and overruns the camp. Sun Quan is surrounded and almost certainly doomed, until Zhou Tai appears from nowhere, his weapons a blur amongst the brazier-lit dark. \\n\\n Though he takes a dozen deep cuts, he drives back the attackers and saves Sun Quan. You go to visit Zhou Tai as he recovers and express your gratitude. His wounds are deep, and will leave brutal scars, but he will endure. He remains characteristically stoic, declaring that he will wear them proudly as a mark of his service to your family.
Bah! Those perennial pests - the rats - are at our supplies. We scatter them, but not before they eat through a large portion of our supplies. The pangs of hunger are already affecting our troops…

Sun Ce, the son of the late Sun Jian has become famed throughout the land for his exploits in conquering the southlands. The people have come to call him 'The Little Conqueror' and you hear it spoken throughout your capital.

As they flee, one of the ragged remnants of a defeated force turns and, in a last desperate attempt, takes aim with a lance, aiming straight at Lady Zhurong. Yet before he can reach the apex of his throw, his arm is seized by the swift stab of a dagger. He falls from his steed, crying out in pain. As Lady Zhurong retrieves her dagger from his body, she muses on the price this foolhardy warrior will fetch for his release.
This defeat is … just a setback! Defeat happens in war, even to those who fight on the side of justice and order. We will bounce back - we must! So many are depending on us!

Your spy, knowing they have your trust, sells the rerouted supplies off to a passing trader. Having rid themselves of any evidence of deception, they forward you a share of their profits from the sale.
Your followers have seized control of expert craftsmen in Taiyuan, as well as a source of iron to supply them. They have wasted no time crafting exquisite new tools to aid your uprising!

Born of a poor family in Zhuo County, you lost your father at a young age. Although a relative of the Imperial Family, you had to weave straw mats and sandals to support your family.\\n\\nWhile somewhat disinterested in studying under your mentor Lu Zhi, you loved to hunt and play music.\\n\\nNow, you seek to serve the Han in any way possible.

The mighty Yangtze, bloated by rainfall, has burst beyond its limits, cascading into the surrounding floodplains. Crops and homes are overwhelmed with the deluge, and the people suffer. \\n\\n Though it is natural causes that precipitated this event, the rain - so say the people - must have been sent by the gods in anger.

It is noble, but desperate, when the untrained man takes up arms to defend his home. And so, behind those walls, that is what the enemy are doing. \\n\\n The old, the infirm and the utterly unqualified are fashioning weapons and standing alongside their trained men, ready to resist our assault.
The future and the past are the same path, stretching out both before you and behind. You have made difficult choices for the future of your faction and while some support this, others take affront.

The Sun clan have become powerful over the years, thanks in no small part to the efforts of Sun Jian and Sun Ce. Now that you are poised to become the strongest in China, this large clan has started showing open hostility. Not surprising, since they probably have the same goal as you: unifying China under a single banner.

You are staggered that two of your comrades, renowned for their inability to make a decision, become friends. \\n\\n The very process of committing to such a kinship seems, to you, impossible for them to achieve. Yet, in defiance of man and heaven, they have somehow achieved it.
It appears that Sima Yi, a famed recluse, has forsaken his isolation to offer his talents to a warlord - a warlord obviously in possession of admirable powers of persuasion!

In uncertain times, preparation for military action is prudent, as are the preservation of things held close to our hearts. The things that make us who we are as individuals, as well as a society, should be kept for all time. The same teachings can thus be learned by the generations that follow.
Kong Rong fought as well as he was able, but ultimately Yuan Shao's power was overwhelming, forcing the proficient governor to yield. Yuan Shao gifts his newly-conquered lands to his son, Yuan Tan.

While misdirecting the enemy army, your spy stumbles upon a hut. Inside is a person of exceptional countenance, but tainted by a bitterness because of the corrupt rule. Sensing a valuable ally, your spy extols your virtue, filling the hermit with new hope and sending them your way.

You call one of your five most loyal generals to assemble in the throne room.\\n\\n "As was the tradition in days of old, I bestow upon you the title of 'tiger general'. Let not anyone doubt your ability and loyalty to the cause."

A swordsman in your realm is known to be unbeatable, and you've enjoyed many evenings watching him defeat challengers in fighting matches. However, one evening, he is challenged by a peasant armed with a simple homemade bamboo staff in place of a sword. \\n\\n The warrior scoffs, but the peasant’s fighting style is unknown to him and he is soon laid low by the deft movement of the staff. \\n\\n You contemplate this and conclude that flexibility is the greatest weapon against chaos, and it is time you yourself studied a new skill.

After noticing the enemy sappers tunnelling beneath our feet, the men quickly set about collapsing the tunnel. The enemy will not sneak past our defences this day, and the men below, entombed in the dirt, stand as a testament to their folly.

This general brings word of a bad omen. Late last night, a mist spread over the stars, obscuring the light above your palace. They interpret this as a warning of the dulling of your rule, and that dissent and disorder may soon follow!

Ambition is laudable, yet this general’s strategies to raise their own standing at the expense of others has not endeared them to their peers. Deceit has won the promotion they coveted, but those they made appear foolish may hinder any further advancements.

The world of dynasties is dying, Zhurong, it is plain to see. Now is the time for those descended from the divine. The other Nanman wait and waste away, while you have the strength, the spirit and the right to rule! Unite the tribes, conquer, and ascend to places of which others could only dream!

Lord Yuan Shao - although you led your coalition to the very gates of the tyrant, your warlords have lost their zeal and fractured, and the fight is not yet done. \\n\\n You must reach out, using your influence and name, to reforge broken bonds and bring together a new coalition as only [[b]]you[[/b]] can! \\n\\n However, be wary of those who would undermine you, especially your avaricious kin, Yuan Shu - for China, you must hold firm!

Skill in battle is good, but being perceptive enough to avoid unnecessary danger is better. This general surveys the land ahead of their army, and judging the terrain to be particularly favourable for enemy ambushes, posts extra guards to be vigilant.

You weep over the body of your fallen progeny, while mourners from your family attend. He was taken too soon, at the hands of your enemies. No father should see their child fall, the grief is impossible to cope with. You seclude yourself away for many days...

Late in the evening, you wander in the garden to contemplate the day’s affairs, only to be attacked by a masked assailant. You draw your dagger and quickly dispatch the would-be-assassin, but to your horror, upon removing their mask, you recognise them as a close and trusted friend. \\n\\n It seems you have become so powerful that people have started to plot against you. It is time to send out your own spies to anticipate such threats, and guard against future treachery.

As the youngest of your three brothers, you've always had a lot to prove. From an early age, you saw yourself as the guardian of your family, keeping your brothers safe from harm. Your eldest brother, Zhang Jue, has now begun his quest to free the land from tyranny, and you have taken up arms with him.

China is known, from northern peaks to southern shores, for summers that draw towards inhospitability. Yet in the south, they are particularly pronounced; muggy, draining affairs which, as if not already unpleasant, are often pelted by hot, torrential rain. Moving in such a muddy deluge, let alone fighting, is an exhausting ordeal.
Shocking news. Dong Zhuo, the vicious tyrant, has deposed the young emperor in favour of his even younger brother! He clearly intends to take power for himself!

In the wake of a dear friend's death, a man appears at court, requesting to be the keeper of your late friend's tomb. There is some suspicion, yet it is Xun You – considered by some to be a fool – who steps forth and demands the man be investigated before employing him. He is subsequently revealed to be none other than the murderer, and as such he is swiftly executed for his crimes.

Some might say that being too trusting is a sure sign of folly, and that ruin follows anyone too easily led. On the contrary, being trusting makes a strong bedrock for friendship, as two of your generals discover. \\n\\n To believe in another's ability not to deceive you is a truly special gift.
The emperor holds you in high regard. As a sign of his favour he has given you a large monetary injection to get your economy back on track.
With this commandery under our control, the things we can do! We can emerge from the shadows of our mountain hideouts and stand, toe-to-toe, with any warlord who dares face us!
Lü Bu, a warrior of rapidly growly reputation, has decided that his current master is not worthy of his service. Tempted by offers of wealth and glory, he gifts their head and lands to Dong Zhuo.
