In the aftermath of the battle, a lone horseman rides out and blocks the path. Full of face and dressed to match, he announces himself as Zhao Yun, offering his services to you.

Your scouts are quick to mention gathering forces along the Yangtze River. They appear to be smaller groups rather than a single large force, split along the bank. Perhaps these are signs of an impending assault?

Yunnan is a land on the cusp of worlds, flanked by sheer and dramatic mountains, filled with placid lakes, and churned up by the thundering drums of war. The tribes here hear such drums, and will always rise to answer such a cadence.

In a state of no small excitement, your general reports that one of your astronomers watched a comet fly across the middle region of the sky late last night. The general is interpreting this as a sign from heaven that a great but unexpected battle is about to take place, though between whom is unknown.
My lord, reports state the Lü Bu has left our camp and established his own faction. Our spies have reported him to have travelled to Xuchang province at the head of a mighty army.
Those who would cast out their saviour and heir-presumptive soon enough find themselves at his mercy.

Xu Shu arrives and meets with his mother. Shamed by her son being so easily duped into betrayal, she commits suicide. Though we gain Xu Shu's services, his advice seems perfunctory and lacks the commitment of his previous talents.

The empire is fallen, Liu Chong; petty tyrants and squabbling warlords have seen to that. Now you are surrounded by such warlords; they have the potential to be a great threat, but their lands are lucrative and waiting to be taken. \\n\\n The conflicts beyond your borders, too, provide opportunity – with warlords distracted fighting one another, you can sweep in with relatively little opposition. \\n\\n You are what remains of a great dynasty, Liu Chong – do not fade away, but rise anew!

You hear a tale of boundless courage in your ranks. One of your generals rides bravely to the aid of his friend, who is moments away from death's cold touch, weathering many blows to defend their comrade. In the aftermath, you take stock of what you have heard and seen...

At the wedding celebrations, King Duosi presents you with a fine gift as a tribute – a beautifully-crafted bow. Inspecting the craftsmanship you can see that this is a weapon fit for a king, and graciously accept the gift and the manner in which it was offered.

As a proud ruler, it was to be expected King Duosi would not take the rejection well, and indeed it would appear that he did not. Yet time heals many wounds; perhaps you can make amends through other means?

You find a messenger outside your quarters who hands you an elegant letter. "I have been given orders to go to Beihai and help out there. It has been a pleasure serving you, and I hope we meet again in more pleasant times."

You watch your general’s boat arrive, but they seem so excited to talk to you, jumping into the water before the boat can dock. Sopping wet, they explain that during their journey a white fish jumped from the water, a sign that nature is offering her gifts to us - proof of a bountiful harvest.

Our siege equipment is gone, destroyed by an apparent landslide! Yet the tell-tale signs of enemy interference are all over the scene; these boulders were definitely loosed by the enemy, and they now have the advantage through our lack of perception.
This death is a disappointment! They were strong, talented and dependable. In their death I have lost a valuable pawn…

Here, where the three streams converge to form the three rivers, is where Meng Huo calls home. The 'Silver Pit' Ravine, as it is known, lies between a valley strewn with the treasures of the earth that lend their name to his ancestral house.

You sit at the border between north and south, but are of neither. You have fought your way to power through guile and skill at arms, bringing both Nanman and Han to heel where they oppose you. A power vacuum grows, and you must be ready to fill it, but you must act swiftly, or others shall assume the mantle which is rightfully yours.

You share a terse exhange of words with Yuan Shao, a one time compatriot. He claims you are a tyrant and seek only to take power over the empire. He marches out of the room, it is only later you hear that he has called a coalition against you; calling you a 'tyrant' and a bully. He doesn't see that a harsh order must be established to end this cycle of violence.

Since the joyous day of your nuptials, your wider duties have caused you to spend much time away from your wife, Lady Zhurong. However, for a love like yours, every reunion is like the first – you feel clumsy and nervous, yet it is clear that  the energy between you has not waned. You choose to spend the next few days together, enjoying one another's company and comfort once more.

Victory takes its toll, it would seem, for Meng Huo has begun to find himself rather comfortable with his repeated successes. So much so, in fact, that some have noticed that he appears to have lost his edge, and his verve and ambition are lacking of late. What can be done about this suddenly diminished zeal?
Pestilence and disease take hold amongst the men - they spread, murky and potent, through the ranks. We must work to quell the infection before it jeopardises the attack, or worse, kills us all!
You are not above threatening violence to extort gold, and besides, if your victims were honourable, they would seek retribution rather than appeasement.

Having lost the battle, you are running to re-join your army when several enemy soldiers block your path. Like wild dogs blinded by bloodlust, they fail to recognise you, only demanding where their quarry is. \\n\\n You tell them you witnessed the coward running in another direction and watch as the fools race off in pursuit.

This administrator fails in one of their most important tasks. When overseeing recent building work, they fail to notice that the bamboo scaffolds have been hastily erected. The entire structure collapses, obviously delaying its completion.

Much like Zhang Zhongjing of old, you have your apprentices make dumplings to hand out to the poor of your lands. This done, you meet members of your clan to pay respects to the ancestors and share a meal together.
Your followers have seized control of expert craftsmen in Taiyuan, as well as a source of iron to supply them. They have wasted no time crafting exquisite new tools to aid your uprising!

As you hold court to discuss the pressing business of the day, your administrator runs into the throne room, bowing profusely in spite of his obvious haste. He recounts that a small force, led by an enemy minister, has snuck through your defences, under cover of night, and spoiled the supplies stored close by. The act was discovered in the early light of the following morning by one of your patrols, along with the bodies of the unfortunate guards murdered during the foray.
Lü Bu, a warrior of rapidly growly reputation, has decided that his current master is not worthy of his service. Tempted by offers of wealth and glory, he gifts their head and lands to Dong Zhuo.

It is difficult for those who are endlessly wary of other people to form friendships, yet this is what transpires. \\n\\n Bizarrely, two of your retinue, both suspicious of almost everything around them, become friends. \\n\\n You can only assume they spend their time together discussing how everyone is out to get them.
No matter your deeds or filial piety, there will always be someone who speaks ill of you. Your only fate is misfortune if such a person happens to have the ear of the emperor.

This season, a small group of refugees braved the dangerous swamps, their perilous journey eventually bringing them to your domain. Respecting their courage and perseverance, you welcome them into the valley as guests, offering the men food and shelter before they continue on their travels. Sitting across from them before a large fire, the refugees share with you stories of their travels and the troubles of the world beyond.

Meng Huo, long has your family lived and thrived in the south. Far from the imperial capital the Southern Tribes, the Nanman, have been left to their own devices. Conflict between tribes, for land or prestige, has not been uncommon, but now it is time for a leader to unite the tribes under a single banner. You are that leader. Rise, Meng Huo, and carve a land from the swamps and jungles of the South.

Another has come to lead our people, uniting all the Nanman tribes under a single banner. Though nominally we follow them, albeit as a lesser power, we must now choose whether to support their kingship wholeheartedly or plot to take the throne for ourselves.

I have good news, my lord. \\n\\n Negotiations with the pirates were successful. Men who have no master but follow coin are surprisingly direct and reliable when paid in advance. \\n\\n They have dispatched ships and will proceed to harass the ports in the area. Their actions will divert valuable resources away from those local lords who have not yet offered us alliance or subservience.
Sun Ce, lord of the Sun family, is ambushed by enemy troops while out hunting. He is shot through the cheek, and dies of his wounds shortly afterwards.

To never forget those who have died in the service of the tribe is a sacred duty that all must honour. In the wake of bloody battle, warriors of all allegiances lay strewn about. You are compelled, as both leader and friend, to lead in tribute to their victorious demise, toasting and chanting to their legacies – may they never be in vain!
Cao Cao Pays His Respects to Yuan Shao

You are undoubtedly the greatest warrior in all of China, Lü Bu - none can question this. However, even you will occasionally suffer from temporary setbacks. The rebels who invited you to lead them against Cao Cao have been found wanting, and were unable to provide your armies with the supplies needed to capitalise on your successes. \\n\\n Perhaps it is wisest to let Cao Cao reclaim the city of Chen as you retreat north, to replenish? Then you can continue prosecuting your vengeance and ensuring your legacy.
The people of this settlement will now know the brilliance of my leadership. In time, more too shall come under my deserving rule!

The Yellow River was ever tumultuous, and now is no different; it has burst its limits, flooding the crops and villages along its usually-nourishing banks. \\n\\n The people are despondent, blaming their suffering and misery upon the government, who have invoked such disasters through their corruption and greed.

A cart arrives in your capital, filled with various goods from across the land. Among the myriad items is a gift from one of your talented armourers – a resplendent suit with a short, inspiring note attached from its maker saying "Only through strength and unity may the land be made whole."

A proficient and tested Wuguo chieftain, Tu An leads his people with great authority and perseverance, forever readying them in the arts of war. His troops are drilled, and drilled again – the blade of Tu An's army endlessly honed for the battles to come.

Seeing his army significantly weakened after a recent battle, Meng Huo sent messengers with tributes to those local chiefs whom he knew well – many from prior struggles to bring peace to the land. The bonds of loyalty are clearly strong among the southern tribes, for the chiefs responded with supplies and fresh troops to aid their king's noble cause.

You arrive to a capital in chaos, as smoke rises from the palace. Your scouts report that the forces loyal to He Jin have broken into the inner residence, slaughtering the eunuchs and all who conspire with them. The walls of the throne room are red with blood and the canals flow with crimson tides.

As you continue to garner support from the elite families of Jing, a member of the powerful Huang family offers to join you. However, such things do not come free. He suggests that should you recompense him in the future, he would be willing to join your cause. You gladly accept.
Not much of a brain between them, but they most certainly can fight!
It seems that, while our treasury flourished from melting the colossi, we've flooded the market and now inflation is rife. It will take some time to resolve this problem.

Whilst rueing the chaos in the empire, you met two great warriors; Zhang Fei, as strong as an ox, and Guan Yu, a man of great prowess. In a peach garden you swore a solemn oath.\\n\\n"Though born of different families, we swear brotherhood. We shall protect one another, serve the state and save the people! We do not seek to be born on the same day, but we do seek to die together! May the heavens smite us should we turn away from the righteous path!"

Luo Jun arrives and you greet each other warmly. "You have completed the tests and passed with flying colours. The land and the people sing your praises. Now, let us go and show the others how it's done!"
Sun Ce's greatest fear was not fulfilling his father ambition of establishing a Sun Dynasty.

It is the day of the Laba Festival. As is the tradition, you gather your officers together and tell the chefs to prepare the traditional Laba Congee; a simple dish while travelling the roads, but the mix of rice, beans and dried fruits lifts the spirits.

Chen Dan has been released from the Northern Yellow Gate. Without evidence or confession, this man stands defiant, though shaken by his treatment. Loyal men are few and far between, and the damage to your relationship by these events will not easily be forgiven.
A noble ideal, perhaps, soured into violent revolution, and silenced by the blade of the worthy.
Victory! The survivors of this battle will run back to their simpering masters, and through feared whispers they shall all know my name before the end…

Many years ago, you both studied under the tutelage of the scholar Lu Zhi. Ever since, you've been steadfast friends and the mutual trust runs deep; coming to one another's aid and visiting frequently to socialise and enjoy each other's company.

The work to ensure your heir is prepared for their future role is almost endless, and you labour tirelessly to ensure they live up to the demands your ambition makes of them. Today, you take a step closer towards that goal, as an aspiration task is now complete! Your heir will thank you when the time comes to inherit.
Fortuitous tidings! Whilst scouting the enemy defences, your forces intercept enemies trying to sneak food past the walls. The forces within, robbed of additional supplies, will surely suffer.

While out on developing farmlands, your attendant was visited a friend in the local commandery. Grabbing a rake, the friend helped while they passed the time together. With two people working, output has drastically improved.

Your general presents you with two golden dragons, excavated during a mining operation. They believe there are still more to be found, and the treasure is destined to come into our possession as the future, rightful rulers of China!

Meng Huo is loyal to his friends and merciless with his enemies. However, he can often be stubborn and brash, with even the smallest slight spiralling out of control and triggering a feud. With his physical strength and booming voice, Meng Huo commands the respect of his peers, having proven himself on the battlefield many times over.

To some, duty is the highest calling. Those who share that belief will doubtless become friends. \\n\\n And so it is with these two, whose shared dedication to their lord and country joins them together. \\n\\n Yet they know that their friendship, strong as it is, is nothing next to their sacred burdens.
We take another step towards enlightenment. We have practiced, studied and focused our minds, and soon all of China, too, will be as harmonious as heaven.

Society demands integration, but some would rather enjoy their own company. \\n\\n You are surprised by the news, then, when two of your comrades, known for their solitary natures, become friends. \\n\\n Though they spend little time together, you know that their kinship is strong.
By holding control of the entire commandery, we can better ensure that we are creating institutions that educate all the people, not just a few. Wisdom shared is twice as valuable!

While fleeing the city, you realise that your wife and child are still inside, surrounded by the enemy! The ever-courageous Zhao Yun rides off alone, battling through enemy lines to reach them. \\n\\n Finding and strapping the child to his back, he then fights his way back to you, delivering your child into your arms.
The seasons pass once more and a new year is upon us. Your ministers have gathered in preparation to carry out their duties, you may hold council when you are ready.

The nights are long, and the siege tests every man's patience. Two friends, looking to while away the hours, are up late drinking and laughing. This morning, however, they are none the better for their night-time revels!
A huge plague of locusts descends upon the fields of China. Many crops are ruined and massive food shortages occur between all people, forcing some to turn to cannibalism in order to survive.
A most joyous occasion! A daughter has been born to your household. Her energy and courage match those of her brothers, perhaps even surpassing them. You have been truly blessed by the heavens!
Liu Chong is Assassinated by Yuan Shu
In a display of staggeringly expected behaviour, Lü Bu has betrayed Liu Bei, seizing a sizable chunk of his territory and declaring his independence.

Your general confides an auspicious omen that came to them in a dream the night before. In the vision, two horns grew out of their head, and an expert in the Book of Changes informed them that this bode their transformation into an ascending creature, like a dragon!

Your attendant has been striving to root out corruption in your commanderies, recently discovering a guard who was taking bribes to allow illicit goods into the city. Your attendant cornered the guard and imprisoned them. The city should be more secure now!
After many nights spent poring over ancient texts, your scholarly court noble discovers a revealing and educational piece from the era of the warring states…

You are awoken from your tent by shouts and a thunderous pounding. You summon your general who reports that a wild white horse with a shock of red for its mane charged into the encampment, trampling some men before disappearing. They say this is an angry spirit and says we should turn back.

Shi Wei, having heard of your prosperity, arrives at the gates. He wishes to join you and help to further nurture these lands. He comes bearing gifts; naturally, you welcome this member of your family with open arms!

Friendship can spring from many sources. Even opposites attract, but more often than not it is like minds that join in friendship. \\n\\n Two more 'distinguished' members of your council become firm companions, sharing tales of their exploits and endeavours. \\n\\n Others may find them insufferable, but what do they care?
Finance Gulf of Tonkin Pirate Raids

Your administrator is offered a bribe by a local businessman to ignore his unscrupulous practices. Offended by the businessman's presumption, and what it infers about their own character, the administrator throws the money at the businessman's feet and calls for his arrest.

Following your loss, you are being chased by Dong Zhuo's men. You pass your distinct red scarf to a trusted attendant, Zu Mao. Dong Zhuo's troops are fooled by the decoy, and pursue him while you escape in the other direction.
For her own security, Lady Sun established a guard of fierce fighting women.

A cart arrives in your capital, filled with various goods from across the land. Among the myriad items is a gift from one of your talented armourers – a resplendent suit with a short, inspiring note attached from its maker saying "Only through strength and unity may the land be made whole."

The baubles and trinkets of diplomacy may seem beneath you, but they are a necessary evil, especially when dealing with the 'nobility' of the Han. However, it seems on this occasion your aim has faltered; the gift you offered was insufficient, and as such the Han have taken great offence to what they view as your 'paltry attempt'.

Much like the wind, subtle but powerful, the humble are the ones who shape China, their movements often going unnoticed. \\n\\n Two modest spirits in your employ are spotted spending more time together, enjoying, it would seem, the company of another courteous soul.

When footsteps are discovered below, and sappers discovered, we immediately set to work smoking them out. After lighting a great fire, the unmistakable coughing is heard, followed by a scurried retreat. The enemy plan to subvert our defences has failed!

Your scouts report raids across your territory – it is the upstart Chen Deng, whose impetuous treason has brought him to your doors. He raids and plunders as he sees fit – this cannot be allowed to continue!

Though the land is divided and under attack from wars and crippled by natural disasters, China still has many brave people ready to fight to restore justice and glory. \\n\\n Word of your goal has spread, and there are now many warriors who admire your ambition and believe you are the one who will reunite China. They are willing to put their faith in your leadership and offer their talents in your service. \\n\\n It is time for you to start recruiting warriors for the long battle ahead.
The Ritual of the Stone Forest

My lord, I have returned from negotiations with the northern mercenaries. \\n\\n The value of gold transcends the barriers of language and culture, and so we have come to a mutually-beneficial agreement. \\n\\n Their warriors now travel south to raid and disrupt the vulnerable commanderies in the area. This is most fortuitous.

You have been appointed as the ruler of Jiaozhi commandery. While this is certainly an honour, this territory is also far from the Han government, far from inspectors, and far from your culture. \\n\\n Many would consider this nomination a veiled insult, but truly, there is boundless opportunity. You can use this land, and its remoteness, to create your own empire within an empire, and secure a future for the Shi family for generations to come.

Your settlement is besieged by an unsurmountable army. Zhuge Liang orders the gates open and sits on a wall playing his lute. \\n\\n The enemy know of his reputation for cunning and read his apparent defencelessness as a clever ruse to ambush them. They call off the attack without a single arrow being shot.

Some say this administrator is born of the wind: they never tire and have such boundless energy that they appear to be in several places at once. Their daily inspections cover all ground within the settlement, causing others to mark time by their visits.

Those who share a love of romance and the arts are destined to be drawn to one another. Harmony is achieved through the kinship of kindred spirits; these two friends find a common interest in their love of the arts.

A runner arrives from the new settlement with a heavy box strapped to his crooked back. Panting heavily, the breathless man slams his bulky consignment down at your feet before collapsing. \\n\\n It is a loot chest with its lock broken open, filled to the brim with jewels and precious trinkets of considerable value.

Proving the efficiency of your reporting network, word has swiftly reached you that one of your expeditionary forces has been constantly beset by enemy raids since embarking on its mission, which has had the disastrous effect of sapping the morale of your soldiers as well as depleting their much-needed supplies. Further discussion with your agents reveals that these raids were led by an enemy minister intent on stopping your advance through the region...

Meng Huo did not watch his back, it would seem. Yet again he has erred and found himself captured and once more he has been released by a kind-hearted – or soft – captor. One can only hope that THIS time he will take better care of himself.
Your general comes to warn you to be vigilant. A snake was caught in the stables last night, and they believe it proves that someone close to you has a duplicitous nature.

Meng Huo did not watch his back, it would seem. Yet again he has erred and found himself captured and once more he has been released by a kind-hearted – or soft – captor. One can only hope that THIS time he will take better care of himself.

When opportunity presents itself, it is not prudent to ignore it. The enemy siege equipment, deployed next to a rather unstable hillside, is poorly positioned; a contingent of men loose the rocks, destroying the equipment below. \\n\\n These men, however, were seconded from other duties, and so the buildings they were repairing remain damaged.
The Rise of the Bandit Queen

When the heat pounds down upon the earth, the land shrivels, the crops wither, and the people suffer. Blighted by heat and starved by drought, they beg the heavens for mercy, finding none. \\n\\n They hurl their ire at the government, whose inaction and corruption, they say, are to blame for the calamities.
This victory is just the beginning - a cautious, tactical beginning. From here, I must continue to consolidate and expand; future victory will come only through careful strategy.

A scholar joins your faction and asks for an audience with you. Begging no disrespect, he tactfully explains that though his previous lord was lacking in leadership qualities, he was in possession of advancements that have thus far evaded your faction. \\n\\n He suggests that there are many useful reforms available to those brave enough to embrace them and states that he recognises this courage in you. You thank him for his counsel and now consider which ideas to take forward as your own.
After having expanded his domain to the corners of the land, Sun Ce began to treat learned and virtuous men with the utmost respect.

Your trusted advisor, Xu You is nowhere to be found. You have searched all around the palace, but to no avail. While you ponder his location, a messenger arrives, Xu You has been seen prostrating himself to your enemy Cao Cao!

The smiths in your forges toil day in and day out, supplying your army. On this occasion, a weapon of considerable quality is produced, such that the smith responsible now comes bearing said item to you, as a gift.

Our defence is compromised! One of your officials - a corrupt and cowardly worm - sneaks out in the night and sabotages the gates. Although he is apprehended, the gates lie in ruins. The enemy will soon pour through!

Many nobles are fortunate to witness this person’s graceful sword dance. The practiced ease of their movements appear as elegant as a feather floating on the winds, each movement flowing effortlessly into the next - inevitable but still beautiful.

The spirit of determination burns in the hearts of many of your warriors and generals, and none more so than these two, whose ardent zeal pushes them not only ever onwards but also into friendship with one another. \\n\\n They are forever trying to better themselves, and together you think they might just do it.

Some love to deceive, to plot and plan; some love to do this alone but some love nothing more than a companion in chicanery. These two friends are developing their camaraderie through ploys and mischief; there seems to be no sign of either stabbing the other in the back... yet.

The tribes remain divided, King Mulu – Meng Huo and Shamoke have emerged as two contenders to the throne; if you are to be victorious, you must be sure not to be overcome! Meanwhile in the north, Liu Zhang commands a threateningly large force of Han troops, and Liu Biao to the east also holds fast to empire lands. Of them all, however, Shi Xie to the south poses the greatest threat to your territory, as he has long looked on them with desire. \\n\\n Your priority must be to unite the tribes, then use their power to defend against the Han!
A New Suit of Armour Forged

Lord Gongsun Zan - China is in chaos but, so far from the capital, there is little you can do to quell the madness; perhaps it is time to utilise your local strength as a respected border lord? \\n\\n Liu Yu, your old mentor, has lost his vigour and his lands may be better managed by you. Likewise, Gongsun Du is kin, but the borders cannot be held by a weak lord. You must consider how [[b]]your[[/b]] presence and power may aid all of China!
Before the dynasty can be established, scores must be settled.
My lord, correspondence has been dispatched to the Confucian scholar. It may be some time before he is able to answer your summons.

Now is our time to break free from his rule! Cao Cao’s eyes turn to his northern border as the overwhelming forces of Yuan Shao move to depose him.\\n\\nReports reach us daily of burning farmland in Runan as Yellow Turban forces continue to incite unrest and gather strength. \\n\\nCao Cao is fighting a war on all fronts, a tribute to his ambition but also a monument to his foolishness. Now we shall move in from the east and use this chaos to our advantage!
Traitors and dogs, conspiring against me? Why can they not see I am doing what MUST be done!? It is irrelevant, I do not need them to see.

A local merchant asks for an audience with you, bringing with them an array of their finest silks as a goodwill gift. As you run the luxurious material through your hands, the merchant hints that if you have any way of improving their fortunes, they would be indebted to you.

Talented, loyal and handsome, Zhou Yu befriended Sun Ce at a young age. The two became inseparable as children and often spent time at each other's residences, showing respect to their families. Zhou’s musical ability is considered peerless and a representation of his keen mind and kind manner.

Lord Liu Bei - Dong Zhuo has seized the emperor, and now wields imperial power to his own tyrannical ends! \\n\\n The Han dynasty must be saved, even if you must take their lands back by force. First, we must defeat the nearby Yellow Turban insurgents, then find a place to build our strength. Nearby, Tao Qian and Kong Rong are Han loyalists who may offer us aid. \\n\\n The time to act, my lord, is now!

In the fading light of day, you and a friend gather for a drink. It is an almost ritualistic time for you both - a time to sit, reflect, and enjoy one another's company. \\n\\n There is seldom time these days, not like there used to be, so you both savour the moment, and each other's company, and fine, FINE wine.

You have worked tirelessly, Lord Liu Yan, to establish yourself in this province, and to follow your ambitions into higher and higher stages. However, time stops for no one, not even one worthy of  the mantle of emperor, and as such, old age creeps closer. \\n\\n We must seriously consider making preparations for your heir to take over your mantle, so that your kin may carry your legacy – standing on the shoulders of giants, no less!

Rebellion rages to the north, Yuan Shu, and although you are fairly safe, the insurrection could possibly stray as far as your lands. Yet with this chaos comes more than a fair share of opportunity; territory could be seized, from which a strong position could be established to continue growing your power. \\n\\n China has never been more ripe for your designs, Yuan Shu – realise them!

Lord Yuan Shu - China is in chaos - there has never been a greater time to realise your own destiny. To succeed, you must be ruthless! Dong Zhuo now holds the emperor in his grip - the coalition against him, under your kin's Yuan Shao's 'leadership', has collapsed, as he is just a blustering fool whose time must soon end. \\n\\n Make friends where you can, but do not hesitate to abandon any who would cross you; let none forestall your ambition!

In the wake of your continued victories, a foreigner arrives at your court, hailing from lands far from your own. Your victories, they say, are worthy of celebration, and offer themselves as a follower and advisor to your rule. For good or for ill, they appear determined to remain in your employ.
A good warrior perishes! A leader of men, a fighter of battles - their loss is all our loss. We must fight all the harder now for their absence.
The mighty warrior and hero Liu Chong has been slain by the coward Yuan Shu. It has been said that he employed assassins to kill the prince during the night.

You have always assisted your brothers in their healing arts. That time was not misspent, as you now know the secrets of the art of healing and other useful ways. With your brothers, you shall bring about a new age, an age where the people will be free from the yoke of oppression.
By bravely leading from the front and his lightning conquest of the south, Sun Ce was by many compared to the great warrior-king Xiang Yu.

A member of your family comes of age. There is much pride and joy at his capping ceremony, where his hair is coiled and his first cap is donned, marking his rise to adulthood. Your family are assisted by their honoured guest, who now joins your kin in his endeavours.

Through a combination of misfortune, lack of supplies, overwhelming forces or sheer indifference, you have failed to uphold your contract. Now all the realm knows of your incompetence and shredded honour.

A captive prisoner is to be released, but before their emancipation, Wei Yan delivers to them a stern, and final warning: should they be caught again, there will be no more pardons, only destruction. The captive flees silently, drained of colour.
By learning from the wise and worthy masters, one is driven to give their all, and then more.

This administrator has a friend in the lumber business, who asks to be granted a building contract in exchange for a reduced rate. Your administrator accepts, leaving them with extra profit and a grateful friend.
What is one man's loss is another's gain. Unhappy with his master's treatment of him Zhang He has surrendered to us. A powerful warrior of great acclaim, he will be a most useful pawn in your ascent.
A promotion is only natural for a man of my talents. With this increased responsibility and power, I will be better placed to enact my plans.

Our enemies will do anything to see us starved out of this place. Adding insult to injury, they intercept all our supply routes and, as a result, starvation and disease are taking hold. The men are dying; we must do something!

Before passing, Zhuge Liang gives final instructions... \\n\\n When the enemy approach later, they see that he still lives, his chariot flanked by his generals, signature fan in hand. The enemy’s horses trample each other in their desperation to flee, unaware that they have only seen a carved decoy.

Furious at the death of his friend, Yan Liang, Wen Chou has gone on a furious killing spree, striking at friend and foe alike. His desire for blood cannot be abated, except by the defeat of his murderers!

Truly dependable friends are rare gifts, and should never be taken for granted. Your comrade, upon seeing you injured in battle, risks his own life to rescue you. They drag you through the hellish battle to safety; you vow never to forget this kindness.

Some people remain friends, in spite of vices that would surely rend others apart. \\n\\n These two are marred by the fault of being unobservant; they barely notice change, and so you must question how they remain friends. Yet they do, and you believe therefore that they must be so astigmatic as to not notice any problem, ever.
One Must Stand; One Must Fall

One of your trusted advisors approaches you with a report of economic matters and how they have been affected by a recent spate of flooding. Thankfully, they remain largely unaffected, but he warns that this is luck rather than prudence. \\n\\n He says that in times of uncertainty it may be wiser to tackle events with more flexibility, and that you are now powerful and influential enough to adapt the old taxation laws of the Han to your own needs.

Dongtuna cares greatly for his subjects. Unlike other lords, who prove their might with weapons and martial strength, he can invariably be found among his people, aiding construction projects and giving alms to the needy. A man of peace, Dongtuna abhors battle, instead seeking more diplomatic means to avoid disaster.

Chen Deng has marched on you again, but this is no raiding party. A much larger force, bent on some greater conquest, now tramples the earth of your territory. This time, your people beg of you, an effective response must be mustered!

You awake to loud noises and shouting, quickly donning your armour and gear in preparation for the worst. After investigating, you discover Hou Cheng and some of his underlings have defected! In doing so they attempted to kidnap one of your generals, but instead resorted to murdering them in cold blood!

The smiths in your forges toil day in and day out, supplying your army. On this occasion, a suit of armour of considerable quality is produced, such that the smith responsible now comes bearing said item to you, as a gift.
Word reaches you that the great Zhuge Liang, self-styled Sleeping Dragon after the ridge near to his home, has offered his services to a warlord he considers worthy of his talents.

As your army enters the small rural village, a man greets you. Large and strong, yet direct and honest, he is truly a man of talent. It is said that while fighting the Yellow Turbans, he singlehandedly pulled an ox by its tail over a hundred steps, striking fear into his enemies' hearts.
Seeing his opportinity for greatness, you advisors inform you that Liu Bei has rebelled against his lord, Cao Cao. You must not decide if this is an opportunity for you as well...

Hearing a commotion outside your personal chambers, you enter the hallway to see it obscured with a long wreath of murky cloud. You grab your nearest general to enquire about the source of the fire, but they tell you there is no fire, just a bad omen warning us that we are straying from the righteous path!

The work to ensure your heir is prepared for their future role is almost endless, and you labour tirelessly to ensure they live up to the demands your ambition makes of them. Today, you take a step closer towards that goal, as an aspiration task is now complete! Your heir will thank you when the time comes to inherit.
Frustrated with an endless duel against the enemy and tiring of swapping exhausted horses for fresh ones, Xu Chu strips off his armour and rides back into battle naked!

On the battlefield, your general faces an enemy who towers far above them. Instead of seizing the chance to prove their talents, they promptly drop their sword and run to fetch an allied soldier of equal stature. That this soldier went on to defeat the foe is the only saving grace in the entire embarrassing episode.
This defeat is painful, but pain can be a potent educator - fall back, make our land more defensible, then let them try to defeat us again!

This general begs your pardon for their lateness, but explains their delay was caused by a carriage wheel breaking during their journey. However, the good news is they believe the accident to be a sign of renewal, an omen that China's ills will soon be replaced by a new harmonious rule.
Your rousing speeches and canny negotiations lead all around to respect you. You have raised relations with a neighbouring faction, and people crave news of your actions.

Guan Yu accepts a duel from an enemy general. Wine is offered, which Guan Yu sets aside, stating "If I should fail, you may take my head". \\n\\n Guan Yu leaps to his mount to the roll of the drums. He returns shortly, the head of his foe resting on his saddle. He takes the wineskin – still warm – and drinks from it.
In Your Hands Lies the Future of China

Even those renowned for bumbling can somehow stumble into friendship. These two are not known for their elegance, but their burgeoning friendship is beyond reproach. You are glad to see it, even if their combined carelessness worries you greatly.
It seems Lady Zhurong has also seen an opportunity here. Hearing of your war against Ahuinan, she has joined and will fight alongside you.
What these warriors share, let no blade nor storm rend asunder.

Furious at the death of his friend, Wen Chou, Yan Liang has gone on a furious killing spree, striking at friend and foe alike. His desire for blood cannot be abated, except by the defeat of his murderers!
Liu Chong is Assassinated by Yuan Shu

To move unseen is a skill few possess, but those who skulk in the dark are seldom the same who make fast friends. \\n\\n Yet sometimes it happens; two of your retinue, used to being a sight unseen, forge a firm friendship in the shadows. \\n\\n What they do is anybody's guess; you can only hope it is not sinister...

You hear a man singing of waiting for a noble lord in the town. Dressed humbly in hempen robes and a turban, he reveals himself to be a great strategist. He is neither Fledgling Phoenix nor Sleeping Dragon, however, but nevertheless still a man of talents.
Sun Jian is killed by Huang Zu at the battle of Xiangyang, cut down in a hail of arrows.

You have under your command many generals of varied ability - the more resourceful among them bringing advantages to situations that otherwise look bleak. \\n\\n Two such enterprising comrades find kinship in one another, and you can only hope it leads to greater ingenuity from them both.

While hunting, your general stops you from shooting a white pheasant, and it escapes. The general explains they have hunted the same pheasant before and it led them to an overhang where they spied an enemy ambush ahead; it could be another friendly warning...
Yuan Shao Succumbs to His Illness

The resourcefulness of the Man people should be cried from every mountain top across the land. With tribal ingenuity, and none of the resources of their Han cousins, they are capable of fording great, torrenting rivers, and building vast bridges. Such bridges, beyond simple mechanisms for travel, can become spots of social gathering and retreat from the bustle of society.
Why should the nobles of the empire be the only ones with significance? I have earned respect, which is more than be said for so many others…

A cart arrives in your capital, filled with various goods from across the land. Among the myriad items is a gift from one of your talented armourers – a resplendent suit with a short, inspiring note attached from its maker saying "Only through strength and unity may the land be made whole."

The master animal trainer from one of your commanderies gifts you a most beautiful horse. "This is a rare specimen that wasn't easy to break in," he claims, "but such is the way with the greatest steeds. This magnificent beast is clearly fit only for one of high station with the utmost courage."
There are decent people in this world no matter the chaos that besets China. It is wise to befriend them when possible, and in turn they will come to your aid when the need arises.

The great, opulent carriages built to reflect our ambition have been burnt to cinders in a tragic accident! Not only was their material worth a tremendous amount, now reduced to nothing, but some are also whispering that this incident might actually be a bad omen from heaven...

The Qingming Festival is upon us once again. As is tradition, you and your men spend the day giving thanks, sweeping the tombs of your ancestors, and drinking libations. \\n\\n Some of your more superstitious followers lay willow branches at the temple gates to ward off wandering evil spirits.

Yuan Shao's faction, once strong now lies in tatters and the sons of Yuan Shao battle over who shall be the leader. Do not fight too long, for the tigers circle the wounded animal, seeking a new meal.

The work to ensure your heir is prepared for their future role is almost endless, and you labour tirelessly to ensure they live up to the demands your ambition makes of them. Today, you take a step closer towards that goal, as an aspiration task is now complete! Your heir will thank you when the time comes to inherit.
With this trade I shall know prosperity. I shall have the finest silks, and throw the most decadent feasts. Only the best for the most deserving inheritor of the throne!
A faction has sought to spread rumours about you within the imperial court. Whether this rumour is beneficial or damaging to your favour with the emperor remains to be seen.

While stealing the item your spy notices a small pouch of gold lying beside it. The heavy responsibility of ownership should not be borne by one so careless, so your spy kindly relieves the owner of further burden by taking the pouch into their 'care'.

You receive a missive from the emperor that you have been given the nine bestowments. Each of these represents a tenet of your greatness and power; wagons and horses, clothes, armed guards, written music, a ramp, a red door, arms, bows and arrows, an axe, and wine are all awarded to you.
Only through union will we see off China's enemies! Alliance, with my guiding hand, will lead us out of the darkness and into the light once more!

Nobles whisper that this general’s destiny is now entwined with another. Strolling through a plum garden, the general met with another, and was struck by their grace. A flurry of complements about each other’s beauty was nervously exchanged, followed by laughter over their mutual attempts at flattery.
Chen Dan's mind was stronger than his body. Whatever secrets this man held he took with him to the grave. Perhaps the eunuchs over-state their ability to extract the truth from mortal men?

What new horror is this! You look upon the charred remnants of your supply lines. The burning husks a monument to your foolishness. Unable to hold back the emotion you strike your sword into the earth and let out a rending scream.

When battle is done, it is heartening to know that there are friends awaiting us, to laugh and tease and make the battle a distant memory. Such a bond is formed between two of your soldiers, and it is heartening to see this companionship enduring and growing over time.
Jiuzhen is in uproar! It is a rebellion, instigated by Chen Bai and Wan Bing. Their insolence has finally fomented an armed insurrection! What is to be done!?
While developing the farmland, your attendant's hoe struck upon a solid object. Digging it up, it turned out to be a chest, containing a most rare object. They have sent it to you with their regards.

You are roused from sleep by a commotion outside. Down in the courtyard, there is a small crowd watching four men. Two of them are preparing to duel, who you recognise as life-long rivals. The other two are each a friend of one of the duellists, there to lend support. \\n\\n Watching them, it occurs to you that friendships and rivalries are equal opposites; both can be immune to reason and logic, regardless if they are born of trivial matters or life-changing events. \\n\\n You leave the men to deal with their quarrel while you retire to ponder your recent new relationship.

Finally, it is finished. After all the work and toil, you have completed your magnum opus, the Nushe Bifa. Inside its gold inlaid cover can be found all the knowledge you have gathered regarding the art of the crossbow. Now, all in your kingdom shall be able to defend themselves should the need arise.

A group of officers, beaten and broken, stumble into your court. They have just come, they say, from a brutal raid in your territory, that they are the unfortunate survivors, that the ferocity of the enemy was beyond them, and that you should sue for peace. This is nonsense, you decry – their lassitude and incompetence staggers you. There will be no peace, you declare, as you mount your horse and kick forward, your beleaguered but loyal men falling in behind you.

China has only continued to slip into further chaos, Yuan Shao – there is clearly still much you must do. Although the tyrant is dead, his absence has only caused more madness: the traitor Lü Bu roams wild, and all around you warlords rise. You could still salvage this land – in fact, [[b]]only[[/b]] you can!

Whereas some administrators rely on a team of clerks for every menial task, this one knows every last detail of their role. Capable of handling three or four wildly divergent tasks at once, their clerks are mainly there for ceremonial purposes.

Stories and rumours abound of your exploits and adventures. One suggests that you and Lu Zheng are not two people, but actually one bandit queen who roams the land - making the tales of your swift, sudden strikes all the more impressive. After all, a little misdirection can only aid your mystique...
I am a debug event, please don't delete my like you did my brothers and sisters.
Your spy succeeds in wounding the target. However, unhappy with their failure, they go the extra mile and smother the wounded victim as they sleep.
A Steed to Rival the Ages
Liu Bei Flees to his Allies
Victory! This is a triumph of the chain of command - military discipline and structures that we have followed for generations will continue to bring us success!
Yuan Shu Plots to kill Liu Chong and Luo Jun

Sun Ce, you have served Yuan Shu as a loyal vassal for four years - since your father's death at the hands of Huang Zu. He has been a capricious and demanding master, but you have served with honour and distinction. However, you will not forget your duty as a son above all – Huang Zu must pay for killing your father. \\n\\n To see your vengeance realised you will need land, warriors and resources. Your family’s homeland of Jiangdong would offer all these things and more. [[b]]Perhaps[[/b]] Yuan Shu can be persuaded to let you take your father’s former generals south and build a base of your own? Until then, you must continue to obey his commands...

The Ten Eunuch Attendants, in their capacity as your advisors, have issued a denunciation of idle, even treasonous talk, and as a result the people grow increasingly bitter towards your administration. Public order is falling in the wake of the eunuchs' continued tenure.
We have brought the corrupt Han to their knees! People shall sing songs of this day; the day when the Yellow Sky rose.
Success! Leading the riders yourself, you tore through the enemy camp, throwing fire on their stores. Before they could even react, you and your rides had disappeared into the night.
Defeat is inexcusable - it was never factored into my strategy. I need to reconsider, rethink, and make sure that this never happens again!

The mind is one's most powerful tool, and when one brilliant mind recognises another, the result is either firm friendship or fierce rivalry. Fortunately, these two find a close bond in their combined exploits, which continues to grow whilst cementing their friendship.

When taking a walk one afternoon, you come across two comrades sparring in a courtyard. You watch their fight with great interest. It is as a dance; they move and flow around each other with strength and grace. You leave the encounter feeling truly energised.

You are brought an item wrapped in cloth - a gift from one of the masters of your arsenal. Pulling away its drapery, you find yourself gazing upon a weapon of exquisite craftsmanship. Such an armament, clearly made by one of considerable skill, is an offering you would be foolish not to accept.

Dong Zhuo has seized the emperor, your kinsman, and wields imperial power in his name!\\n\\nThe Han Dynasty must be saved. Reclaim nearby lands and build an army which would be able to defeat the tyrant and save your kin.\\n\\nThe Han will endure!

Lord Ma Teng - Dong Zhuo has fled west with the emperor, yet he remains the best option for maintaining the Han for now. You too must secure your borders against any and all threats, including the nearby Yellow Turbans. Han Sui may be a loyal ally, but if he shows weakness then seek others! \\n\\n There is no denying Dong Zhuo's growing desperation, however, so if he becomes vulnerable, you must be ready to move against him to defend the empire as you are sworn to!

The emperor, fearful of his life and future, had a decree calling for a coalition against Cao Cao secreted into a jade girdle, which was handed to Dong Cheng. Liu Bei and Ma Teng both chose to sign the petition, declaring themselves enemies of Cao Cao.

You ask this general the cause of their recent sombre moods, hoping to put your considerable powers to help alleviate them. When they confess it is merely that no-one has complemented their new silken robes, you have to supress your laughter!
There can be no quarter for traitors. None. All must face the sword - mercy is for the weak, and I must show unrelenting strength!
Your sappers report back; rather than risking a collapse by digging through the vein of clay, they work around it. Although safer, this increases their digging time.
Riches lay strewn about, unattended, at the mouth of the Yangtze, like so many coins in a busy market, waiting to be taken…
The grasp of the barbarians unravels and reveals to me this city - and opportunity! From here, I could educate so many, and lift the cloud of darkness from these times!

Upon retiring to your chambers for the evening, you discover a gift prepared for you upon the bed. It says little upon it, only bearing the signature of Meng Huo. One of your courtiers, it would seem, was induced by the king to deliver it to you here.
Every traitor who opposes me will be destroyed! I cannot brook any resistance - what I do, I do to keep order!

This spy does not use elaborate disguises but strives to be as normal as possible. Their clothes are drab but not dirty, their gait neither strident or subdued, and in conversation they appear to hold no controversial views. They are never the target of attention, and few would even remember their presence.
With just a piece of stone, Sun Ce was able to inherit his father's dauntless commanders.
The future and the past are the same path, stretching out both before you and behind. You have made difficult choices for the future of your faction and while some support this, others take affront.

Once advisor to the Wu forces, Pang Tong is well regarded as a man of great talent. The 'Fledgling Phoenix' hailed from Jing province, but was dismissed from his post. Pang Tong has many recommendations to make, should you wish to hire him.

One of your generals made the unfortunate mistake of holding back when sparring with your sister. Incensed by her opponent's lack of sincerity, feeling insulted and with temper high, she gave him no quarter in the following round. Unfortunately, the sound drubbing that followed has strained the relationship between the two somewhat.

One of your generals sends a runner from the new settlement, reportedly carrying a valuable consignment. He is immediately brought before your throne, kneeling to present you with a lavishly decorated chest with a broken lock. \\n\\n You open it to reveal a most valuable item within; a treasure amongst treasures!

Some things are made to last while others wither. The assessment made about his person played on Cao Cao's mind. "In times of peace you will be a good servant", Cao Cao felt that his destiny was not in serving others but he believed in the dynasty of the Han. "In times of strife you will be a dangerous chief", This made Cao Cao smile and wonder what he would make of the empire were he in control.

You watch in awe as Gang Ning uses his chain to scale the enemy wall as if he sprinting across land! He reaches the top, grabs the head of the watch commander and flips the unfortunate soldier over his back, sending him plummeting to his death below.

A beam of golden light pierces the heavens, shining a small warm ray over our farmlands. One of your generals says this is a promise of a good harvest, and that the people will surely eat well this season.

Meng Huo was not more vigilant. Having repeated his previous folly, he has fallen into your clutches yet again. Your magnanimity seems to know no bounds; you let him go once more. Perhaps next time he will watch his back?

Disease spreads through the ranks, but not a natural pestilence, but man-made poison! An enemy agent must have infected our water supplies; there is no telling how long this will take to run its course…

As a token of generosity for all that you do, a local stable owner has brought to you the finest steed in his pastures – a powerful horse, dark as the deepest pit and as enduring as the earth itself. Such a gift is beyond your words to thank, but you accept it humbly all the same.

Emperor Xian, the rightful heir to the Han throne and last vestige of its dynasty, has finally taken his place at the imperial palace under your mentorship. While you have led your people well, gaining prestige and stability, the task to unite China is now in divine hands.
Your general reports on the ongoing sapping operation. Although encountering a deep vein of rock, they are able to skilfully dig through it and are progressing to the enemy walls.

Misery, it would seem, is often piled upon misery. The enemy find luck - one of their shots strikes true, landing upon one of our buildings. The blow, frustratingly, destroys a crucial beam, and the entire structure collapses. \\n\\n The men are shaken by what they have seen, and worry for our defences...

A young soldier comes before you in the street and kneels, presenting himself as the son of the peasant farmer whose life you spared. Returning home after serving his duties, he sees a family pulled from the brink of starvation. He weeps tears of gratitude and pledges service to you for as long as he continues to draw breath.
Not all action must be overt - the unseen fly can travel where the tiger cannot. By sending out a spy, I can move unseen, but have all revealed to me.
The captain of the centre, the leader of the professional Northern Army, has pledged his allegiance to Cao Cao. He now has a formidable force at his disposal.

Although never confirmed, it is whispered and rumoured than Lady Zhurong is descended from the eponymous god of fire. And though they be but murmurs, the people believe them, and choose to follow her to the most bitter of ends. Although their lives would be forfeit by riding into the jaws of death, they care not; such is the loyalty she fosters amongst her people.
The Emperor, Liu Hong, is dead. It appears he has perished of natural causes, but his death has caused chaos across the lands.

It seems that not everyone is happy with your tax collector's efforts - they have been accosted while out collecting tithes and their gold has been stolen! While the instigators have been dealt with, the stolen coin was never found.

The serpent is a venerable creature in our culture, worthy of tribute and devotion. The construction of a shrine is a fitting tribute, and so you raise the timbers on an ornate memorial to the slithering snake, in the hopes your devotions will eventually bring rewards.
A great lineage, brought low by arrogance, disinclination, and the strength of a peerless warrior.

Retreating from a losing battle, your general sees some stranded allies encircled by the enemy. With the kind of frenzy only borne through defeat, the general pounces upon the enemy soldiers, driving them back as if a mighty hurricane, allowing the allies the time to escape.

The city bustles with life. Fish merchants sell their wares by the docks, while clerks work in the administration office. Scholars flock to your city, bringing knowledge and ideas. You have set-up your legacy, a powerbase fit for the greatest.
The Bandit Queen, Zheng Jiang, has left our service. It seems that she has struck out on her own in the North. Worse still, she appears to have stolen some gold from the treasury!
With the attack on the Sun clan started, the last remaining major match of strategy begins. If you can overcome this enemy, surely China itself will bow to your will?

The days of noble rebellion may be fading, Gong Du, yet the war is far from over. You have aligned yourself with Yuan Shao and Liu Bei against Cao Cao, but the situation is grim. Without a wise strategy you are unlikely to survive. \\n\\n To the south, Liu Biao maintains a strong presence; your first goal should be to survive against this rising power. Look for friends, if you can – the Yellow Turbans are all-but gone, so you will need to form new bonds. \\n\\n Hold fast, Gong Du, and pray that your noble goals survive in an ignoble time.
The warlord, Yuan Shao, has sent out a call to arms. All able bodied men must band together, to dislodge the serpent which has coiled itself around the legitimate throne of the emperor.

Meng Huo did not watch his back, it would seem. Yet again he has erred and found himself captured and once more he has been released by a kind-hearted – or soft – captor. One can only hope that THIS time he will take better care of himself.

When your general sees injustice, there is no force that can dampen their fury. On overhearing an administrator insult their friend, your general’s ears turn red and their eyebrows furrow. \\n\\n With a blood curdling roar, they punch the administrator squarely on the nose, and then have to walk off their rage!

This administrator closely observes news of crops, trade routes, factions and the weather; by keeping abreast of any changes and comparing them against seemingly unrelated events, they can predict and manipulate the fortunes of the local markets.

With the soldiers in a weakened and starved state, your spy sells their own stolen supplies back to them! Too tired and desperate to question where this sudden bounty came from, the soldiers pay without argument.

Many great virtues are demanded of those deemed fit to rule. When someone lacking virtues takes control, only chaos can ensue. This Dong Zhuo is such a person, and it would be a calamity to the state if he were allowed into the capital.

Honour dictates action; you should only act with pure and noble intentions. \\n\\n The friendship developing between two of your more principled companions, then, can only come from equally noble beginnings.
Fathers influence all children with their presence, their lack thereof, and everything inbetween.

Battle is brutal and, above all, wearying. In the aftermath, you and a comrade, exhausted, sit to share tea. As the steam rises, silence reigns but for the pouring of the brew and trickle of the rain. No words are exchanged, for they are not needed. \\n\\n Through silence, and presence, you both find a moment of harmony.

A cart arrives in your capital, filled with various goods from across the land. Among the myriad items is a gift from one of your talented armourers – a resplendent suit with a short, inspiring note attached from its maker saying "Only through strength and unity may the land be made whole."

Construction of a new building within the colonised town suddenly stops. The building site is located on some old ruins where terrified workers claim to have seen the restless ghosts of the previous occupants. \\n\\n Your superstitious general in the locality orders that no-one go near the area.

When overhearing a farmer’s woes about finding his pigs and goats slaughtered, your general takes you aside. They are certain that this was done to gather blood to exorcise some nearby witchcraft, and recommends you sleep in a different room to fool evil spirits while they investigate.

The devastation wrought by the locust plague proves that farming and regular food supplies are vital for a robust military force. You vow to keep your armies supplied, no matter the cost. \\n\\n You increase the number of farms in your lands, build forts, and employ soldiers, who can double as farmhands.

The mountains tremble beneath the weight of the land's troubles. One such mountain, unable to bear such tribulations, has collapsed in upon itself, shaking the firmament of the dynasty. \\n\\n The people can see this no other way: heaven has demonstrated its fury with the rulers of the land.
Following your recent success, the captain of the Northern Army has come to pledge his devotion to you. He brings with him the full might of the professional army he commands.

A courier is brought before you. Not of the Nanman but of the Han – their route south to deliver news to Shi Xie has led them astray into your lands. Information is a valuable commodity, and with some hospitality (and wine...) the courier shares with you news of internal strife within the Han. Men with ambition seek to grow their power; the weak are consumed and those who act with wisdom may survive or even prosper. Over the course of the evening you ply what information you can of your imperial neighbours...

The bonds of brother and sisterhood are all that some need to push them on towards victory. \\n\\n The link of kinship between these two warriors does just that, tying them together like the roots of a mighty tree. \\n\\n May this bond hold them together through all adversity.

Xi Ni is a Wuguo in his heart and soul; the lie of the land is etched into his mind as a molten brand upon flesh. Every peril and each boon of his country is known to him; he has learned to live off, and defend himself with, the land around him.
The Yellow Turbans Rise Once More
As ambitions bring rising conflict among the Nanman, friends become allies and rivals become enemies. Duosi and his people have joined with Shamoke to save their fury for a common foes.

It's been a long time since you've seen your sworn kin. China is vast, and the country's needs are many; you've been separated, in the name of progress, for so long. Upon being reunited, there is little anyone can do to stop you embracing, overjoyed at finally seeing one another again.
Sun Ce, having been called to action in a dream, promised to restore this mountain temple.
Zhang Yan heads to the Black Mountain
A New Suit of Armour Forged

At a victory feast in a forest clearing, this general forsakes alcohol to remain pure. While others are intoxicated, the general’s unclouded senses detect encroaching enemy scouts. Feigning drunkenness, the general staggers close enough to draw their blade, scaring them away.
This death is a tragedy, yet we should take heart that they died in service to our noble cause - their death may pave the way for our future victories!
Cao Cao is Granted the County of Chen
To be so blind to reason… I despair for them, and for our land. Only through unity can the common folk be freed from oppression, and the chaos be banished.

The peace you have so long strived for is shattering, Kong Rong - torn apart by the ambitions of tyrants and warlords. It is clear now you cannot sit idly by and let the land be pulled down by this madness; though you have been loath to even consider it, it is past time to ride to war in the name of restoring peace!
Liu Chong is Assassinated by Yuan Shu

The 'shih', or educated gentlemen, are a rare breed that exemplify everything a citizen should aspire to. One such man is identified and then idealised by his local community as bringing harmony and inspiration to everyone around him.
A member of your spy's guanxi network, extremely competent and sympathetic to our cause, now patiently awaits you at your court.

My Lord, terrible news has arrived from the capital. It seems that, during the commotion, your sons Liu Fan and Liu Dan have been cut down! We should have saved them when we had the chance, but now it is too late. May the grief and guilt you must feel propel you forward and strengthen your resolve to save China from the chaos that consumes it!

A gift has been sent to you by your estranged brother, Yuan Shu. Opening the package releases an almost metallic odour, the bindings loosen, and the head of one of your officials clumsily rolls out of the paper, bloodying the floor.
Today marked the day of the Qixi Festival celebrating the ancient love story of Zhinu and Niulang, who followed one another, even into the celestial realm, as their love could not be broken.
Liu Bei has fallen at Cao Cao's hand and fled, tail between his legs, to Yuan Shao. However, it seems one of the brothers, Guan Yu has not joined the exodus, and his whereabouts are unknown.

From beyond the walls, you hear muffled screaming amidst the sound of collapsing masonry. It seems that, in their eagerness, enemy sappers dug too far, too fast, and their tunnel has collapsed. That was lucky!

A collapsed bridge in one of your settlements is causing delays in food and goods logistics. \\n\\n Though there are enough materials and the construction work is simple, with enough bodies to carry it out, progress is prevented by two squabbling village elders. Each blames the other’s grandfather for inferior building work on the old bridge, and demands they fund the new one. \\n\\n After time is wasted searching village records to prove their claim, you hear of this and decide it is time to appoint administrators who can ensure the village is run with a practical and measured mind.

The mustering of troops goes well, but your attendant reports that one of your generals has helped them out. As well as deepening their bond, the general's presence inspires the brave and the bold to enlist in your armies.

While your men were establishing order in the newly-annexed town, a disgruntled civilian lashes out at one of your officers in a heated altercation and attempts to kill him. \\n\\n Your officer has the wherewithal to defend himself and even manages to kill his attacker, but is badly wounded in the scuffle.
The old ways are dying, and any who abandon MY cause are re-joining the morass of the Han. They shall all fall, and I shall rise! I do not need them!
This commandery yields to me - I claim it back for the emperor, and hope that he sees in these actions my skill and unwavering loyalty.
That snake Liu Bei, whom you have supped with and had taken as a friend, has finally cast off his vestiges of humility and risen against you. You will not let this stand...
Another faction is given the nine bestowments. Their path to emperorship is clearly set.

Your general confides a terrible omen they dreamt of last night: a vision of two horns growing out of their head. The word 'horn' is composed of two parts, ‘knife’ and ‘use’, and they predict this means a knife is upon their head.
With this first victory, we take a great step towards toppling a hated regime, a corrupt empire, and establishing true harmony across China!

Over the past seven years you have tirelessly toiled to build these barren southern lands into something beautiful. Your labours now begin to bear fruit, and so you must not relent now, to ensure their continued growth and improvement. \\n\\nConsolidate all the lands you have the right to, and then if the flames of ambition still burn brightly in your heart, turn your gaze northwards, to divided, vulnerable China...
Yuan Shu's Arrogance Knows No Bounds

A true artist instinctively knows when their work is complete; you lay down your brush and read the words of your poem, satisfied that you have mastered the art:\\n\\n[[i]]"I lift my drink and sing a song, for who knows if one's life is short or long,\\nMan's life is like the morning dew, past days many future days few,\\nThe melancholy my heart begets, comes from cares I cannot forget,\\nWho can unravel these sorrows of mine? I know of only one man, the god of wine."[[/i]]

A schism has split your advisors. Some say we must recognise the rising power in the east and pledge allegiance to a new and rising Han dynasty. Others balk at the suggestion, calling it tantamount to cowardly surrender. You are not obliged to choose who has the right of it, but your court – and thus, your society – will be split along these lines for some time.

Whilst some would prefer to watch the days go by in placid harmony, others are determined to go forth and seize that sinking sun. \\n\\n A friendship forms of this boundless zeal, as two of your warriors find companionship in their endless adventures. \\n\\n To watch them is exhausting, but heartening.

Can friendship bloom on the battlefield? It would appear so, as two comrades find comfort in one another; laughing, training and dining together. Their bond is emblematic of the strength that will reunify China.

Traders arriving from the south via Yunnan have spoken of the events unfolding there. It seems that in recent months powerful tribal leaders have begun to settle their differences through violent means. It is clear that the balance of power in Nanzhong has shifted – we should watch the situation carefully.

With war now a distant memory, you read and analysed the two books that fortuitously came into your possession. One day, a tree in the gardens of the capital is unexpectedly struck by lightning, its trunk torn asunder to reveal the final book of the three, unharmed – the Way of Peace is restored!

The siege engineers you requested have been assigned to your force for the rest of the year. \\n\\nOnce a settlement has been encircled they will assemble battering rams and siege towers, allowing our forces to assault almost immediately. Even the strongest walls shall fall under our assault.
With your military struggling to combat the challenges it faces, the emperor has decided to give you soldiers and supplies to aid in the defence of your lands.

Our enemy is insipid, and wily… the men you sent to sap beneath their defences are discovered! The foes collapse the tunnel, dashing our hopes and trapping the noble sappers. \\n\\n There is little hope of rescuing them now; our plans to swiftly end this siege, too, are now doomed.

The reports of increased pirate activity in Bohai Bay have spread among the coastal settlements. In such times of strife wicked men are emboldened, preying upon the weak with no regard for law or morality.

While on a hunting excursion, you are set upon by bandits! A cursed horse Hex Mark may be, but while making your escape he leaps over a river wider than any a horse should be able to cross, securing your safety. \\n\\n The eluded brigands stand astonished on the other bank, confounded by the impossible feat!
The captain of the centre, the leader of the professional Northern Army, has pledged his allegiance to Yuan Shao. He now has a formidable force at his disposal.
To secure the dynasty's future, one most find capable generals before their talent is noticed by others.

Two brothers, their bonds forged in war and strengthened by strife, sit around a campfire in the dimming light of evening. They share tales of glory and memories of friends long gone. \\n\\n Their smiles are wistful and their thoughts bittersweet, but they are glad above all to have one another for support.
Imperial Favour: The Emperor sends aid to your troops

To celebrate their name day, this court noble throws a modest event at their house with a select few friends and relatives, humbly asking them to provide their own refreshments to ease the burden of the cost.

The peoples of Zangke are agriculturally minded, and have been so for many, many centuries. That they have settled along the plains and rivers of China is no surprise then, nor it is a surprise that they are fiercely independent against all who threaten their simple way of life.

Emperor Xian has been restored to his rightful place on the imperial throne. Those who have supported him now step aside to allow him to lead China into a shining new era. The Han dynasty has been restored!

Lord Kong Rong - chaos surrounds you! The Yellow Turban rebellion spreads like wildfire through your lands - you must snuff them out! \\n\\n You must then act to bring an end to Dong Zhuo's greed - the Han falters as his grand treason tears the land apart. Liu Bei, an honourable man, could be a firm ally as you build power against the tyrant. \\n\\n The time is now, my lord - China has great need of your wisdom!

A friend has tipped of your attendant to a great business opportunity within the local commandery, which would aid their investment strategy. Seizing this opportunity, your attendant has made greater profits than expected.
Your general witnesses a white rainbow and warns you that a rainbow bled of colour is a perversion and a bad omen, though exactly what it warns of they cannot be certain.

Your armies are drilled and drilled and drilled again; a strong military is supported at all times by a core of unfailing discipline. \\n\\n Two of your generals, staunch in their rigid routines, find friendship through their shared love of military styles. They do nearly everything together, at precisely the right moment.

The least that you can do for your men is to ensure they can work and fight well together. There are those, however, that simply cannot abide one another's presence. Two such warriors are so embittered they cannot stand to look at each other. This may become a problem if left unchecked.

It is reported that Sun Ce has perished, and with his death leadership passes to another. Although his demise will send ripples across China, it is certain that his successor and brother, Sun Quan, will allow no weakness to show under his command.
One defeat cannot hold us back! If you push us down, so many more of us will rise - our enemies will be drowned by our tide of justice!

Worrying missives reach you that the Yellow Turbans have once again risen against the Han. They are lead by Liu Pi, a zealous individual with only once goal, to depose you and depose the emperor. At least he recognises where the true power lies...

This general’s cautious nature has been unjustly misconstrued as cowardice. However, while leading their troops through a forest, the general ordered all to halt. Poking the leafy ground ahead with a spear caused the ground to give way, revealing a pit trap. Now their warnings are listened to with respect!

As the night draws in, you hear the sounds of celebration in the distance. Distracted from your meditations, you see hundreds upon hundreds of brightly-coloured paper lanterns hanging from every house and tree. The sight is truly beautiful to behold!

My lord, our artisans have completed a beautiful set of carriages to transport you in comfort through the kingdom. While some ill-advised fools may claim you are unworthy of such finery, these are truly opulent crafts, reflecting not only your status but your higher purpose also!

As the enemy is fleeing, you can see smoke coming from their camp. The fire was caused by two great warriors, Jiang Qin and Zhou Tai. The men have been living as pirates and have long heard of your greatness, they ask to aid you in campaign.
Zhao Wei has risen in rebellion of you, Liu Zhang! There is nothing that can be done to assuage his feelings and quell this treason. You must prepare for his onslaught!
Aha. That is not correct, because according to the encyclopaedia of…

The ability to observe, and see what others may not, is highly valuable in both war and friendship; just so for two of your more astute, observant comrades.\\n\\n  The ability to understand the subtleties of another person can make you a more receptive and sympathetic person, and a better friend.

It pays to deal with the 'noble' dynasties in the manner to which they are accustomed; opulent gifts and sycophantic tribute. Such measures do not always work, even on the avaricious Han, but in this instance the arrow flies true. You are viewed now with greater pleasure – long may it continue.
