Having your work recognised by anyone is a great thing, but imperial recognition is divine. The 'General of the Gentlemen of the Household of the North' will defend the empire against all of its enemies!
Yuan Shu has been spreading vicious and scurrilous rumours about you to everyone he meets; his hatred for you surpasses any other.
As your troops flee in panic, a lone horseman rides out and blocks the enemy advance. Full of face and dressed to match, he announces himself as Zhao Yun, offering his services to you.

The sun’s light was swallowed by an all-encompassing darkness, sending your general into a panic. They declare to all who will listen that the darkness foretells some evil deed perpetrated by your enemies.

My lord, we have sent arms and military advisors to support the rebel forces. They are poised to attack the local garrison, should they succeed we should aim to 'liberate' the settlement before other interests seize the opportunity.
Messages have reached you that the warlord Yuan Shu has declared himself the emperor under heaven. Such a brazen act has angered many, but he has also drawn powerful nobles to his cause.

This person’s loyalty is as unshakeable as a great oak. For them, loyalty is not a matter of shifting allegiance to whoever holds power, but a permanent oath to a single person, never to be broken under any consequences.

The empress has stepped from the shadow of the eunuchs to issue her own proclamation, declaring the people as the backbone of the realm, their hard work supporting the Han during a time of such crisis. A show of such appreciation has endeared the people to hear, and by extension, the Han. Yet the eunuchs do not appreciate her meddling...

Zheng Jiang, the land is being consumed by chaos, but it is in chaos that you thrive! None in this world have accepted you and none have welcomed you, so you must make your own world - one where you rule! \\n\\n Alliances may be of temporary use, yet there are very few warlords that you should trust. Any who oppose you in your quest for your glory should be destroyed - all will bow to the Bandit Queen!
Meng Huo has found himself in chains, captured after your last battle. You have chosen to release him. There is no knowing how the next battle will play out, but he will surely be more vigilant…
We have claimed our first victory in the name of the emperor! If the Han is to be protected, we must forge on and score many more like this!

The tribes of the Wuhuan are an ever-present threat to your northern borders. However, as a seasoned veteran, you know that a white horse is a sacred animal to them, and to kill one is a grave sin.\\n\\n You exploit this by fielding swathes of white horses to strike fear into their hearts, instantly giving you power over them.
Terrible news from the capital! The schemes of the Eunuchs have come to a head and they have assassinated a high ranking official!

Long had you dutifully served the Han, held up as one of the eight geniuses of Jiangxia. However your forthright nature caught the attention of the corrupt eunuchs, who censored you and drove you from the capital. Far away from the culture and schools of Luoyang, you find yourself in an unfamiliar landscape.

A local festival lights up the night in one of the tribal territories, and Lady Zhurong herself is spotted moving amongst the crowds of revellers. She moves and dances along with them, and takes time to pay tribute both to the people themselves, and the god of fire, Zhurong, from whom – it is said – the lady takes her own name.

My lord, your scouts report that Yuan Shao has succumbed to his illness and passed. No doubt the in-fighting amongst his family and the stresses of war contributed to the elderly warlord's declining health. No doubt his sons will be eager to take control, but now is the time to use the chaos and uncertainty to your advantage and claim the north!

Luo Jun comes to you, a wooden box underneath his arm. He sits while you offer him some tea, which he receives with a bow. "My friend, you have been good to me and I seek nothing more that to be of service in our mission to calm these turbulent lands. With this in mind, I have brought you a gift." He opens the box, revealing an exquisite crossbow of singular quality.

This general spots a black and red crane perched on the roof of one of your administrators. The crane screeches at the door four times, then flies off to the south. \\n\\n Your general is certain this is the physical form of the Southern Dipper, and that the administrator will soon be blessed with a child.

He Yi - the tyrant has thrown China into even greater chaos! Heaven has abandoned the Han - you must lead the Yellow Turbans to claim the Mandate of Heaven and restore peace. Yet the Han still has might, so you must not charge recklessly into the fray. \\n\\n We are outnumbered, so we must build our strength gradually. Consolidate the nearby commanderies, defeating any Han loyalists who oppose you. Endure their onslaughts, then strike! A Yellow Sky [[b]]will[[/b]] rise!

The smiths in your forges toil day in and day out, supplying your army. On this occasion, an item of considerable quality is produced, such that the smith responsible now comes bearing said item to you, as a gift.

This general has a true heart and the gift to convey it through clear and inspiring words. Even the hardest embittered soul cannot help but be moved by their charisma and gravitas. Recently, they gave hope to one whose faith was wavering, fully restoring that individual's belief in our faction’s ideals.

Luxuries of silk and jade are nothing for this general compared to the love of family. Close friends and relatives are all the treasures they need to feel fulfilment, and these they maintain through simple respect and honour. If only all people were as easily content.

Despite the clash of swords and bitter conflicts that stood between you both, there was a time where you called Yuan Shao an ally. Looking down upon his gravesite, you cannot help but remember those times. Suddenly, the memories of gruelling battles you fought against each other begin to relent, as memories of your past coalition to free the emperor overtake them. Standing over a foe's grave should bring with it a feeling of triumph for a warlord such as you, but, alas, you struggle to truly declare Yuan Shao an enemy.

The power of strong administration must not be underestimated. As such, whilst reviewing your daily reports, you come across a message stating that a baggage train has been discovered, its attendant recruits killed and its supplies looted. A lone survivor was found hiding nearby. He recounts that an enemy general rode in on horseback and single-handedly dispatched the guards before disappearing again into the wilderness. Could this really be the work of one individual?

After completing their mission, your spy encounters an enemy general. Hoping to dispel any suspicion, the spy endures a lengthy and tedious conversation with the general about his gaudy new silk robe, only to be saved when he is called away on more pressing matters.

Zhurong, you are thrust onto a stage not of your making, yet you must make it your own all the same. The world is in chaos, and your contemporaries – for the most part – are content to do nothing. If the tribes are to be united, and a power restored to these parts, then let it be your power. You are descended of gods, Zhurong – now is your time to ascend!

This general demands a high level of discipline from their troops, to match their own. Each morning, their troops are woken for a 10 li training run before breakfast; any stragglers are penalised by having to do an extra li the following day!

To be truly wise is to surround yourself with other like-minded souls. These two find friendship in each other, with intelligence enough to know such a thing is rare and so should be nurtured. For cleverness is not just knowing facts, but knowing feelings, too.
Through tireless effort on behalf of the people, we will grow stronger as warriors and as kin. In this way, there is nothing that we cannot do.
Zhang Hong has long been a friend of the Sun family. In order to support your endeavours, he has penned a pair of biographies detailing the achievements of your father and brother.
In weakening the garrison, the morale of the troops has dipped low. Rather than looking to the horizon for enemies, they slouch and look at their feet in defeatism.

The lush and varied foliage of Jianning makes it one of the most stunning vistas in all of China, and subsequently one of the most desired. Yet its people are here to stay, and will fight against any invader, to whatever bitter end.

As you proceed through the annexed settlement, one of your officers brings an ornate chest before you, sealed with a heavy lock. You strike it firmly with your blade, breaking the chest open to reveal its contents – jewels, valuable trinkets, and wondrous treasures.

The arrogance of Yuan Shu continues to grow unabated, only fuelling his undeserved and unpredictable ambitions. By declaring himself emperor, the time may have come where his lust for power must be checked, in lieu of stern words, by cold steel.

With your lands at peace, you find your mind seeking greater enlightenment. One day, while out walking, you encounter a cave-dwelling hermit who hands you a scroll. It is one of three, he claims. \\n\\n As he shuffles back into his den, you hear him whisper. "Only through continued peace will the mysteries be revealed..."

The work to ensure your heir is prepared for their future role is almost endless, and you labour tirelessly to ensure they live up to the demands your ambition makes of them. Today, you take a step closer towards that goal, as an aspiration task is now complete! Your heir will thank you when the time comes to inherit.
The minister Wang Yun, fearing the tyranny of Dong Zhuo, sends his adopted daughter to the capital. His plan is to have her destroy the relationship between Dong Zhuo and his adopted son, Lü Bu.
These people flock, like naïve birds, to shiny baubles that glitter and attract the eye. These new trinkets will not last, and neither will these turncoats.
Any comrade of mine is a brother-in-arms! I mourn their loss as I would my own family. And more than that, I will avenge them!

Yang Feng keeps his mind sharper than his blade. Although a born and tried leader of warriors, his true passion is the great game of politics; he plays the fool to lull his foes, all the while probing and exploiting their true weaknesses.

Your scouts report forces with Zhang Meng's banners raised have begun marching into your lands. No doubt Zhang Meng has realised the strategic importance of Shoufang to the north as well, as his armies have been spotted traversing such areas also.

A jade icon thought to foretell good fortune has disappeared! You order the guards to search, but they find nothing. Your general believes it is because of the chaos that fouls the land; destiny itself has become blurred and uncertain, causing important items to shift and be misplaced.

Your war to unite the tribes is not yet over, Shamoke; both Meng Huo and Mulu still oppose your efforts. Beyond them, the Han vassal Liu Zhang controls a large and loyal force to the north, whilst Liu Biao awaits to the east. Shi Xie, meanwhile, has long been tasked with subduing the southern tribes, so you should be wary. Once you unify them – and you certainly must unify them – the Han beyond can be dealt with!
Yuan Shao shall feel this sting. Xu You, a man of great talent, has decided to join you, forsaking his former master Yuan Shao. This is a good day to write some poetry, you think to yourself...
The emperor has placed a military sanction on you due to your overtly aggressive actions.

When two warriors become friends, a certain level of bravado is to be expected from such a kinship. These two become close, their bond driven by shared courage on the battlefield. Theirs is a friendship forged in war, and strengthened by time.

There are none who can resist the allure of gifts. Everyone has a price, even the most principled and honourable Nanman. Yet if the price is not right, joy turns to ash. Such it is with this gift, lavishly offered but insultingly received. It does not meet expectations, and thus you are now viewed with considerably less favour than before.
This city is just the beginning of my fury - I will become the name that the decadent Han fear to speak, lest they invoke my rage.

Scouts on the battlement report new flags on the horizon, which can mean only one thing; the enemy are bringing reinforcements! With these additional troops, it is almost certain they will overwhelm the walls with brute force. We must prepare for the worst...

The work to ensure your heir is prepared for their future role is almost endless, and you labour tirelessly to ensure they live up to the demands your ambition makes of them. Today, you take a step closer towards that goal, as an aspiration task is now complete! Your heir will thank you when the time comes to inherit.

Your general refuses to celebrate a victory in battle while allies still lie wounded on the battlefield. Injured troops, three at a time, are personally rescued and carried on horseback to be treated, before the general rides out to collect more.

Even before the battle commences, Zhuge Liang’s greatness shines through. \\n\\n Challenged to a debate by an enemy minister, Zhuge proclaims him a dog and a traitor, and the old minister falls from the horse, dead.

A test of strength is only natural amongst good-natured comrades, and to settle long-simmering rivalries. A tournament! Bold and brash displays of power crash against one another with howls of passion and rings of steel, until one warrior emerges, at last, victorious!

Autumn has come, and with it the swell of the rivers. Your generals, sensing opportunity, take it upon themselves to burst a nearby dam. The resulting floodwaters sweep down and destroy an enemy village utterly.

Your advisors have informed you that a trader, with a fine menagerie of animals for sale, has been spotted entering our borders. Quality livestock such as this does not come cheap, however, so we may have to save our funds for next season, in the hope that they will return then bearing the same abundance.

Cheng Pu has fought many battles in his long and storied career. One of your younger generals has taken to calling him 'Elder Cheng' as a mark of respect. The name spreads quickly, much to Cheng Pu's disgruntlement.

Your general claims to have sent several expeditions to the fabled Mount Penglai to secure a 'mushroom of immortality'. Despite losing some to its mighty peaks, the general swears to have partaken of the legendary mushroom and that, as a result, they will never age. \\n\\n You cannot verify this, but their skin does appear healthier...
A Steed to Rival the Ages

Liu Bei, reflecting upon his beginnings as a shoemaker to where he is now, is feeling dejected at having fought for so long. Yet his achievements do not align with his dreams of becoming emperor, fighting others' battles. Finally, he decides that it is time for the winds of war to change in his favour.

As old alliances shatter and reform in the crucible of war, friends become enemies, only to become friends again. A warrior in your service finds an old companion, returned to fight on the same side. They come to you now to present their sword to your service.

The wheels of diplomacy are lubricated by the passing of trinkets and gifts; the Nanman are no more immune to this form of flattery than any other. In this instance, the gifts were deemed appropriate, for no offence has been taken. Quite the contrary, they seem most pleased, and as a result find you much more endearing than before.
Although you cannot tell why, the sight of enemies fleeing their tunnels in the distance indicates something has gone wrong down below, and their sapping attempt has been aborted.
Sun Jian is killed by Huang Zu at the battle of Xiangyang, cut down in a hail of arrows.

The poison of the poison marshes, they say, comes from the falling leaves above the water, toxic to any who has not lived alongside them. Others, however, believe Duosi's magic to hold some power over them. Regardless, they are thus quite deadly to Han invaders, which they soon discover when Duosi leads them deep into the marshes as they try, once more, to conquer his lands...

You have welcomed Lü Bu into your faction, but he is clearly discontented. He argues with your other officers and makes increasingly outrageous demands. Action must be taken soon, lest the matter escalate.
The tyrant, Dong Zhuo, has set Luoyang ablaze! The black, repugnant smoke rises to the heavens, and is an affront to all.

Jealousy often festers into something far uglier and more dangerous: one of your generals emerges victorious from battle, only to suffer a mysterious, but fortunately not fatal, injury. \\n\\n There are reports that a rival of his, having recently feuded with the general, was seen heading his direction during the battle's aftermath...

You are woken from slumber with important news. Your general has found the missing jade icon... or rather, it has reappeared! \\n\\n The general swears that its sudden reappearance is because recent events have restored some peace to the land, once again fixing destiny and repairing what was once broken.

It has begun! Across the lands, the banners of the Yellow Turbans are being raised, hastened by the defection of Tang Zhou.\\n\\nA call to arms has gone up from the emperor, and all across the lands, troops are being gathered to defend the empire from this threat, as brother fights against brother.
The wise should always seek to advance, to teach other their wisdom - and so I have endeavoured to this point. There is much we can all learn and teach, we must stay focused!

Assassins have made an attempt not just on your life, but also that of your closest advisor, Luo Jun. Thankfully you were able to fight them off, but not before learning their source: Yuan Shu, the vile cur!
Zhou Yu understood the importance of the Jing province. From its advantageous position, one may march on the great plains or the Riverland's with impunity.

When the blood rises, and battle descends, all manner of dark and unspeakable deeds transpire. How people reconcile with those deeds in the aftermath is the true test of a warrior. Yet for Meng Huo and Zhurong, their bond is only strengthened by their the fires of warfare.

Dark tidings! During the night, an enemy sortie slips through our defences and torches our food supplies! Although we are able to save some food, much is lost. The men feel both pangs of hunger and of despair…

Your general is so distracted they bump into you. You ask them what ails them, and they explain that their astrological signs are misaligned, meaning their future is in disarray. You try to reassure them, but they take little comfort from your words.
Not satisfied with winning the battle, our general overtakes the retreating enemy troops and lays a successful ambush, further reducing the numbers that can stand against us.

Ma Chao, it seems, can wait no longer. Such is his hatred of Cao Cao, he has left you to take up arms against his despised foe. If he should survive, it is not known if he will then return to your side...
Your spy’s efforts to improve relations are given extra weight when a trusted friend of influence appears to corroborate their assertions in court.

Your trials and tribulations with the people have won you their love; your care and dedication to helping everyone you meet are clear and obvious to all. The people who follow you are gladdened to be in your presence and the warriors who fight for you do so with an ever-more earnest zeal.

The empress, like a creeping vine, has wrapped around and choked the emperor. Her tyranny cannot continue, so you have declared yourself in open revolt. The only option now is to march on the capital and free the emperor from the clutches of his wife!

It is reported that the sound of enemy digging has not gone away; in fact, if anything, it has grown louder! They are clearly advancing far faster than we anticipated. We should prepare for their imminent arrival!

Peace reigns across your lands. As if guided by an unseen force, you find yourself in a small shop just off the thoroughfare, filled with all manner of antiques. \\n\\n The shopkeeper, an elderly and bedraggled man, hands you a scroll. "I believe this is what you seek," he croaks, "...and you have but one more book to find."

As the target leaves the faction, there is much weeping, and tears of sorrow soak the ground. A great feast is held outside the city walls and the faction warlord comes out to personally escort the target out of the city. Even our spy feels their lip tremble in sympathy.
With allies by our side, there is nothing we cannot do! Together, we will shore up our ideals and our government, and hold fast against all interlopers!
Yuan Shu brings you a gift, a fine and thoughtful item which he hopes demonstrates the love and respect he fosters for his new-found brother

A treacherous underling, Hao Meng, has rebelled against you. You are caught off-guard, and forced to flee in your nightwear – but thanks to the loyalty and resolve of a young officer named Cao Xing, the rebellion is quashed, and you are spared an ignoble demise.
The target is driven from their faction by your spy's machinations, but without knowing of this, they blame their former master, declaring an oath of vengeance against him!
Jiang Qin & Zhou Tai Join Your Faction
This position is an increase in responsibility and privilege! I am certain that, in time, the world will know my name!

A group of officers, beaten and broken, stumble into your court. They have just come, they say, from a brutal raid in your territory, that they are the unfortunate survivors, that the ferocity of the enemy was beyond them, and that you should sue for peace. This is nonsense, you decry – their lassitude and incompetence staggers you. There will be no peace, you declare, as you mount your horse and kick forward, your beleaguered but loyal men falling in behind you.
Word has spread to a neighbouring region through your diligent efforts, triggering an uprising. You must now choose whether to help the rebellion or let it fend for itself and join you later.
Their loss is my gain! The Black Mountain Bandits ride out and defeat any in their way! Unstoppable!
As a lonely stranger in a foreign land,\\nAt every holiday my homesickness increases.\\nFar away, I know my brothers have reached the peak;\\nThey are wearing the zhuyu, but one is not present.
You come across a large contingent of troops, at their head is a stout warrior, Cao Ren, your cousin. After an informal greeting he offers to aid you in your quest.

As your army retreats over a bridge, you turn and stand like a great oak to block pursuers. Many bodies fall to your blade and clog the river below. By the time you are forced to break off your defence and re-join your allies on the other side, the water is a deep crimson.
A Strong Daughter is Born to Sun Jian

Retinues led by your most adept captains continue to demonstrate that their ability to out-manoeuvre and strike down those who oppose you has not gone unnoticed. Sharp, silky about-faces, deftly decisive movements and the ability to follow your every command on the battlefield has led to deadly results in your favour. Efficient, loyal and now deadly – quite the combination. \\n\\n"[[i]]The good fighter will be terrible in his onset, and prompt in his actions.[[/i]]" – Sun Tzu

You muster your forces, ready to set out and take on the Yellow Turbans, your new brothers in tow. However, you lack horses and weapons for the battle.\\n\\nFortuitiously, a pair of horse traders arrive who, upon hearing of the quest, agreed to give the brothers horses and money for arms. The blacksmiths are summoned, creating fine weapons for each of them.
Shocking news. Dong Zhuo, the vicious tyrant, has deposed the young emperor in favour of his even younger brother! He clearly intends to take power for himself!

Upon returning to a robe discarded during a garden walk, you see one of your generals waiting for you with it in their hands. They say while you were gone, a black serpent dropped from a tree and coiled itself around your robe before slithering off, and that this is an omen that a tragedy awaits you.

The work to ensure your heir is prepared for their future role is almost endless, and you labour tirelessly to ensure they live up to the demands your ambition makes of them. Today, you take a step closer towards that goal, as an aspiration task is now complete! Your heir will thank you when the time comes to inherit.

It is regrettable that your people must seek preservation with axe in hand.\\n\\nThe great gathering of the Nanman people beneath a single banner - your banner - has spread unease through the Han kingdoms. Some may seek to bend you, others seek to break you.
This minister is solitary and keeps themselves to themselves. Having been mentioned by name in a missive, they shrink away from it and look as troubled as if they had been summoned for execution.

Grave news! Your rule in this land is not as strong as you thought, and the cunning emperor has slipped from your grasp. Without a strong power base and the prestige to back it, the emperor found it easy to bribe his way out of your court. The traitors will pay for this!
The death of one, even one so influential, cannot stop the Yellow Turban. Our rebellion is build on ideals, not people, and those ideals will carry us to victory!

The charismatic will invariably attract others to their charm and gusto, yet two of the same type of people may bounce off one another. Not so with these two, who flow together like streams merging into a river. \\n\\n Their friendship blossoms with verve and energy; all are gladdened to see it.

China is falling to chaos, Ma Teng, but here in the west you are relatively secure. Rebellion blossoms everywhere, so you must look to secure your own defences first, before attempting to aid the emperor. \\n\\n In the northwest, you must consolidate your strength and your territory, then turn your eyes east, and to what can be done to defeat the growing insurrections.

Those pitiful fools in the capital strut like peacocks! You have achieved greatness from your upbringing as a humble farmer, and yet they constantly overlook your majesty. Your ambition was written in the stars and confirmed by your discovery of the Blade of Xiang Yu, the hegemon-king. But, mark your words, they will see your true ability, and your name shall be writ large on the annals of history!
The mighty warrior and hero Liu Chong has been slain by the coward Yuan Shu. It has been said that he employed assassins to kill the prince during the night.

The Duanwu Festival is a momentous day! Drinks are poured freely and the smell of food fills the air. As you celebrate the honour of Qu Yuan, the teams pull their Dragon Boats through the river with much clamour and cheering from the banks. By a truly breathtakingly slim margin, your team rows to victory - glory is yours!

You have fought boldly, each of your warriors fighting with the unbreakable strength of a thousand or more. Yet now, that strength is spent, and the fire within you all gutters and fades. It will take time, and recuperation, before you can draw on such power again. In the meantime, you had best hope the enemy does not seek to retaliate now, of all times...

Lord Sun Jian - you are far from home, it is time you returned south. The coalition is finished and the tyrant's wrath will soon be felt, so only from a strong position in the southlands can you hope to weather the coming storm, then expand your influence. \\n\\n  You must be wary - Liu Biao is ageing but crafty - untrustworthy and all-too close, whilst Yuan Shu is ambitious but potentially useful. \\n\\n Let none stand in the way of your ambition!

After a frustrating evening of trying unsuccessfully to untangle a tricky economic problem, you confide your inability to solve the conundrum to a close friend. He offers to play some soothing music to console you, but the noise he creates seems more like punishment. \\n\\n When you tell him his playing is terrible, he replies. "Of course, I am no musician! Do not waste your time grappling with things outside of your expertise, or you will only cause more harm, and leave no time for the things you can affect." \\n\\n You decide it is time to hire some ministers to aid you. And a musician.

A solid friend is worth more than a thousand unknown soldiers. As you lie recovering from a battle, a comrade tells the tale of your friend who took great risk - and great injury - to save you in the fray. You survived because of them. They survived too, but not without bearing the battle's scars.

You hear rumours of Three Brothers of the Zhang family from Julu county, who have been gathering many followers to their side. It is said, that one day, while gathering herbs, one of the brothers was visited by an old man, who handed them a book of three volumes, The Essential Arts of Great Peace. It was said that whoever held this book would be able to bring peace to all mankind. The group have begun calling themselves the Yellow Turbans, due to the scarves they wear on their heads.
Messages have reached you that the warlord Yuan Shu has declared himself the emperor under heaven. Such a brazen act has angered many, but he has also drawn powerful nobles to his cause.

As the son of Sun Jian and head of the Sun family, you have exceeded even your father's famed exploits, uniting large swathes of the southlands under your control. The people have begun calling you the 'Little Conqueror', a term you rather loathe.

While travelling, you meet a young cowherd playing the flute. Intrigued, you speak with him, and he takes you to his master, Water Mirror, an old hermit living in the mountains. \\n\\n Water Mirror says "If you could only find Fledgling Phoenix or Sleeping Dragon, you would be able to restore the order to the empire".

Your advisors have informed you that a trader, with a fine menagerie of animals for sale, has been spotted entering our borders. Quality livestock such as this does not come cheap, however, so we may have to save our funds for next season, in the hope that they will return then bearing the same abundance.

A magnificent feast is erected outside the city gates to honour Xu Shu as he prepares to leave. You escort Xu Shu out, and before bidding a tearful farewell, he tells you to seek one called Sleeping Dragon; a man of great genius whose talents at debate exceed his own.

Vanity is almost certainly a vice, but not the worst, as long as it doesn't sour into narcissism. Yet you fail to see how these two companions found friendship in one another; joined by their shared vanity, perhaps? \\n\\n Although they are together a lot, they spend most of their time gazing into the nearest reflective surface.
As this commandery yields to us, all of China knows we are slowly restoring order, and that we will not rest until all chaos is banished, and the Han's power is restored!
Promising talent sometimes hails from the least expected of places. A feisty young warrior, barely an adult yet demonstrating the keenest martial prowess, is yours to command if you so choose.

The burden of a vengeful duty that long clouded this general's happiness is finally lifted. Through sheer chance, they encounter their target on a lonely road, and satisfy their responsibility once and for all.

Like fireflies to the ever-tempting flame, the incompetent somehow gravitate towards each other. \\n\\n These two inept individuals find friendship in one another, somehow, and you can only hope this leads to their betterment, and not the opposite!
The Young Emperor Comes of Age

Fate is fickle, and luck is oft a deciding factor in battle. The enemy, with an entirely lucky shot, exposes a pre-existing weakness in our defences. We must be ready for an attack; unless they are canny they will squander this chance!

On several occasions, you have chosen to make your own appointments to vacant official positions in the south. The imperial court's impatience with your perceived impertinence has only grown as a result. Subsequently, they have appointed Shi Xie as General Who Pacifies the South - a clear attempt to limit your control.
With each new trade agreement, we all grow wiser and more prosperous. The people will thank us for our endeavour, as indeed will our coin-keepers!

It is heartening to see your comrades getting along. These two find they have much in common, joined together by a common bond of self-discipline and austerity. Whilst seeming severe and po-faced to others, the pair appear glad of one another's company.

Gonsun Zan - you have, through myriad misfortunes, found yourself upon hard times. But your luck can change! Although Liu Yu is gone, and Xianyu Fu now stands opposed to you, fate has been kind of enough to grant you a reprieve from Yuan Shao, at least. \\n\\n Seek an advantage against him and the others – perhaps the mountain bandits – and re-secure your home!
Under your enlightened guidance, the people live in harmony and contentment.

Your general steps outside to go hunting as a violent monsoon howls and batters the walls. The hunting trip was only mentioned in jest because of the storm, but your obstinate general sees it as a challenge and cannot be dissuaded!

There are those who know the hidden ways and secrets of the mountains. Those who do not know are doomed to eternal ignorance. If allowed to fester, this ignorance will spread like a weed to infest all those touched by its numbing influence. Do not ignore those who know...

A general regales a recent battle. In particular, he mentions a mutual friend of yours who, seeing another in a dire situation, leaps to his defence. His blade, it is said, appears to be moved by heaven itself, finding its mark, felling the foe, and saving the friend. His courage is commendable!

Sometimes, even seemingly-independent people can find friendship in like-minded souls. These two, driven by their own desire to achieve, draw inspiration - or perhaps competition - from one another. \\n\\n It gladdens you to see it - but with a laugh, you wonder where it can possibly end?
The emperor has placed an economic sanction on you due to your overtly aggressive actions.

Born into the greatest family of his local area, Jinhuansanjie became king of the ravine at a young age, having lost his father while still only a child. Through the great adversity of his life, he has never lost sight of the need to help his people and raise them from penury.

The comfort of camp can leave the constant warrior bored and restless, so Wutugu leaves in the early hours of the morning. In the mid-afternoon he is seen walking back into camp, clearly invigorated and in good spirits. About his neck hang several teeth larger than a man's hand. Rumours quickly circulate, each more extravagant than the last, as to the size of the beast Wutugu had laid low.

Your general has a reputation for discipline, but has recently started taking sadistic pleasure in punishment. Even people accused of imagined slights or misdeeds are flogged, their suffering justified as 'deterrents to future crimes', and there are few soldiers in their army who remain unscarred by the whip.

As you proceed through the annexed settlement, one of your officers brings an ornate chest before you, sealed with a heavy lock. You strike it firmly with your blade, breaking the chest open to reveal its contents – a most valuable item, a treasure amongst treasures!

Taking advantage of the division between his regents, the emperor has slipped their grasp and called upon loyal warlords to defend him. Already, many have answered the call, and have taken him to the former capital of Luoyang.\\n\\nYour close advisor, Xun Yu, spots an opportunity – if the emperor is in need of a protector, surely you are the best option?

A chance to spar with a good friend arises; a rare opportunity in these frantic times. You confess to being a little out of practice as you begin, and soon find yourself on the end of a flurry of blows that you simply cannot anticipate. \\n\\n After falling to the floor one too many times, you concede, vowing to do better next time!

Of all the traits most valued in a friendship, patience must be amongst the most important. The patience to deal with one another's flaws is beyond worth. \\n\\n Two of your comrades, both patient more than most, find friendship, in which you can only assume they will find an otherworldly harmony.

While trying to dig through the seam of soft clay before them, our sappers disturb the harmony of the tunnel, and it collapses on top of them. Your general is prostrate before you, apologetic, but there is nothing more to do be done. We must begin the tunnel again.

A friend of yours, full of zeal, challenges you to spar - and who are you to resist? As you size up, you feel good, strong, ready. And surely enough, when the fight starts, you soon land blow after blow in a dazzling demonstration of skill. \\n\\n Before long, and laughing, your friend has no choice but to yield.

The faction's mantle has been passed on to another. It is now up to the heir – nay, the new leader – to guide this faction to glory, using whatever tools their predecessor left behind for the purpose.
The Fall of the Tyrant's Empire

Construction of a new building within the colonised town suddenly stops. The building site is located on some old ruins where terrified workers claim to have seen the restless ghosts of the previous occupants, so they are refusing to go anywhere near it.
Shocking news, the young emperor has been seized by one who seeks only to use them as a mere puppet. This is an affront to the han!

That ungrateful sot! Despite accepting your gifts, Lü Bu leaked your plan to Ding Yuan. Now he has marshalled his forces and prepares for war against you! No matter. What politics cannot achieve, the blade will hew away!
The bonds of friendship will be China's salvation. You see that two of your warriors are spending more and more time together. Laughing, training, ribbing; such a bond can only be beneficial.

Lord Dong Zhuo - you were wise to move west, protecting the emperor from those traitors! Their coalition is all but spent now - they will face imperial justice in time, but first you must secure your position. \\n\\n Chang'an is well protected but you must expand, crushing dissent wherever it occurs. Although there are warlords still loyal to you and the Han, you must ensure their fealty never wavers - all traitors must be put to the sword!
In a move that you should possibly have expected, Lü Bu has betrayed you by rebelling against your rule. Take up arms against him, and repay his treachery with blood!

Solemnly, you kneel at the graveside of your loyal officer and place their pottery sculpture into it. Although you had your share of disagreements along the way, they served you honestly – which is not something that can be said of all your compatriots. Something bothers you about this death, however, and you cannot shake it from your mind: an enemy officer was seen speaking with the physician who tended them shortly before your attendant's demise...

This general’s sense of duty is as vital to them as the blood that flows in their veins, and the ideals of our faction hold them upright as much as their bones. Their allegiance is beyond question, and every thought and action they have are guided by the principle of duty to the great cause.
Through wisdom we gain greater power! Through our power we make solid our edifices and ideals - we can protect our future!

A beautiful jade ornament has come into this general's possession. Although the explanation of where and how the treasure acquired was elusive, it is believed to be heaven’s confirmation that our faction is destined to lead the empire! They wanted you to know the news immediately.

Far in the west, dotted by mountains and wetlands, Yongchang seems entirely unwilling to give itself up to any invaders, as do its people. The land is often rocked by tremors – proof that the earth itself is angry at the Han's greed?

Betrayal! Perhaps this should have been anticipated? Nevertheless, the feast descends into a gruesome bloodbath, as your neighbour turns on you and begins the slaughter. Although you escape unharmed, it is very clear that this was a singular, direct declaration of war!

News of your great deeds has spread far and wide. With your warriors shouting your name and your banners flying across the lands, your legacy is writ large upon China. Should you wish it, you may now ascend to even greater levels of power.\\n\\n[[i]]Increasing your Progression Level, from the Faction Summary screen, allows you to increase your capacities and unlock more diplomatic actions.[[/i]]

In light of your co-operation towards mutual goals the envoy returns, with gifts and a formalised treaty between your two factions. May this man's skills help strengthen our future relationship, and serve you well.

A tiger prowling in the camp panics the guards. The screams awake your general, who leaps from their tent half-dressed and wrestles the beast to the ground until it is properly subdued. Moments later, another tiger’s roar is heard, but it turns out to be the contented snores of your general coming from his tent...
You send word far and wide that you are seeking talented people to join your court. One has been found who fits your needs, and they await your decision.

You are betrayed, Cao Cao! While you were prosecuting justice against Tao Qian, and seeking revenge for your murdered father, your vassals in Chen turned against you. In their madness they invited the treacherous rogue Lü Bu to lead them! \\n\\n Now you have returned, and the rebels are on the run – you should begin by reclaiming your lost territory, before then destroying those who dared to betray you!
Yuan Shao battles Gongsun Zan, taking control of the provinces northeast of the Yellow River. This puts them at great odds with one another, forcing them into war.
Trade is the true statecraft of gentlemen! Amicable agreements in a tumultuous world - we should all strive for trade and diplomacy to light our way through the dark.

Travelling through hostile lands, your spy leaps clear of a pit trap, but fumbles the landing and cartwheels over a steep hill. Rapidly rolling down the hill, they barrel into the enemy spy that set the trap and instantly break their rival's neck. A complete fiasco has been prevented through sheer clumsiness!

A local merchant, indebted to your spy for increasing their coffers, presents you with a gift: a large basket of his richest herbs and spices, with a parchment detailing how best to apply them. He hopes you accept this gift and remember his gratitude.

Our sapping mission ends in failure, lord! Our team, digging beneath the enemy settlement, are discovered and smoked out. They return to us now, coughing profusely but otherwise none the worse for the experience. We will have to try something else.
This city falls to our might! We must drive forward, knowing that we act in a just cause - that of the emperor, and thus all of China!
Two former generals of Dong Zhuo's faction, Guo Si and Li Jue, have rebelled in the capital, sowing further chaos within the tyrant's faction.

The smiths in your forges toil day in and day out, supplying your army. On this occasion, a suit of armour of considerable quality is produced, such that the smith responsible now comes bearing said item to you, as a gift.
Your followers have seized control of expert craftsmen in Taiyuan, as well as a source of iron to supply them. They have wasted no time crafting exquisite new tools to aid your uprising!

Charity inevitably draws the charitable. Those who strive to be outgoing and generous often band together, like mountains before a growing storm: stalwart and implacable. Friendship between two altruistic souls is growing, and China itself will benefit from such companionship.

Once a week, this administrator tours their area, providing food for the poorer civilians and listening to their concerns. News of the administrator's arrival brings the inhabitants out to greet them and thank them for their care and attention beyond simple matters of bureaucracy.

Lü Bu intervenes in an argument between officials. He pushes them apart and grabs a bow from a nearby soldier. A halberd is set up over 150 paces away, and Lü Bu declares that if he is to hit the left branch of it, all will disperse. \\n\\n He pulls back the string, lets fly, and makes the impossible shot.

Your scouts report that the forces loyal to He Jin have broken into the inner residence, slaughtering the eunuchs and all who conspire with them. The walls of the throne room are red with blood and the canals flow with crimson tides.

One of our greatest Xiangqi players challenges your general. The match goes on for many hours, and though their opponent displays a higher level of skill, the general's careful patience is enough to sustain victory.

Some love to deceive, to plot and plan; some love to do this alone but some love nothing more than a companion in chicanery. \\n\\n These two friends are developing their camaraderie through ploys and mischief; there seems to be no sign of either stabbing the other in the back... yet.
Sun Jian is killed by Huang Zu at the battle of Xiangyang, cut down in a hail of arrows.

In a local village square you see some crude archery buttes erected and villagers taking turns to fire arrows into them. Children are spectating, cheering whenever their favourite strikes the target. A man, tall of stature and fine of face, trains them. "Who is he?" you ask a passer-by. "Huang Zhong, a great warrior who trains us to defend ourselves from bandits." You offer him a position, which he gladly accepts.

War is relentless and destructive; there are those who - rightly or wrongly - choose to avoid such conflict when they can. \\n\\n Two such souls in your retinue find friendship over their combined disdain for war. They spend much time together, painting or... singing or... whatever it is pacifists do.
For the good of relations between Wu and Shu, the Lady Sun Ren and Lord Liu have married. May this joyous day be felt across the empires!

As the current incumbent upon the throne and recipient of the Mandate of Heaven, many across China will hold the word of Emperor Xian in the highest regard. Warlords across the country will be ambitiously seeking imperial favour through showing how they have brought prosperity to their people and defeat to the emperor's foes. \\n\\nCrushing the enemies of the Han and maintaining a happy population with food in their bellies will likely sway his favour, but with such power resting on the shoulders of someone so young comes an increased risk of manipulation and skulduggery at less scrupulous hands than your own. \\n\\nStaying in the emperor's good graces will be important in the years to come, but ensuring he does not favour your enemies may prove to be just as important...

This general’s passion for competition often manifests in their opponents' injuries. A game of cuju takes a surprising turn when they eliminate the best player on the opposing team by hurling them through a fence. Few challenge the general afterwards, and, as you might expect, they win the match.

Meng Huo did not watch his back, it would seem. Yet again he has erred and found himself captured and once more he has been released by a kind-hearted – or soft – captor. One can only hope that THIS time he will take better care of himself.

Twin dragons of northern China are now locked in conflict. On one side, the honourable Yuan Shao and on the other, the cunning Cao Cao. This conflict, a long boded reckoning could decide not just the rate of the north, but of China itself.

Your heir waits in the wings for an opportunity to take the mantle, but if they must wait too long, their enthusiasm will start to wane. Soon, if action is not taken, your heir’s prospects will change, and not for the better.

There is art in subtlety but truth in being direct. Truth forms the solid bedrock of a strong friendship, built to last. \\n\\n Two of your retinue, unflinchingly honest, are building their friendship on this basis; never afraid to tell one another the hard truths, their bond is wrought in them.

Having won the battle, all sit around feasting and enjoying music. However, even after drinking a great amount, Zhou Yu recognises and winces at a sour note. \\n\\n He stops the music and takes the xinhua from the musician, then motions for everyone to start playing again, joining in with a fluid ease.

Several long years have passed, Liu Bei, since the coalition ended and you were forced to forge on without them. Since then, the tyrant has been slain, yet the land is no closer to reunification. You must continue to strive onwards against all enemies, to restore the Han to glory, save the emperor, and thwart the ambitions of those would seek to tear the dynasty down!
The art of war is as the art of life. Proceed too fast or too slow, and you will come to ruin.

As the timbers rise on your ever-growing tribe, you are approached by one of the prominent figures in your recent constructions. He offers admiration for your attempts to invigorate the tribe and its standing, and as such would serve you directly, if you would have him, presenting his skill in construction to your employ.

It is often the nature of men that they argue. Some, however, argue more than others, so obstinate are they in their beliefs. This stubbornness can often limit friendship, but not so in the case of two of your generals. \\n\\n They form a bond, even in spite of their hot-headed self-belief.

Once again, this administrator’s suspicious nature deprives them of a tidy profit. Simply because a merchant has a slight slope of brow, they dismiss them as a charlatan, only for a colleague of theirs to take up the offer and reap a handsome reward.

The land shakes violently; it cracks and breaks, causing panic and destruction. In its wake, homes are ruined and communities devastated. \\n\\n Although there are provisions in place to aid them, the people cast their scorn at the government for displeasing heaven and inciting their wrath.

As war grows, lines are drawn as everyone chooses a side. A warrior has come to you, promising their sword in service to your cause. They have heard your call to arms and will gladly fight in your name.

King Mulu, long have you defended, with an unmatched power, against those who would seek to corrupt and pollute the land. Now, that strength is required more than ever, to unite the tribes against enemies within and without. The Han looms large, whilst the tribes threaten to tear each other apart. Unite them, Mulu, and let land and beast prosper once again!
The Zhang brothers have been crushed and their rebellion dies with them, while some remnants may remain, they are no longer a threat to the Han Empire. This is a glorious victory!

Your spy's work towards bolstering the garrison has been more successful than we could have hoped for. The troops feel a new sense of pride in their readiness, raising morale and inspiring greater service from each of them.

Taking advantage of the division between his regents, the emperor has slipped their grasp and called upon loyal warlords to defend him. Already, many have answered the call, and have taken him to the former capital of Luoyang.
That father of warlord Cao Cao has been killed by soldiers bearing the banner of Tao Qian. Word is that Cao Cao will only be satisfied with blood, and has vowed to wipe Tao Qian out in retaliation.

Lord Zhang Yan - the warlords of China have descended into civil war; perhaps the time has come for you to descend from the mountains and make yourself known? Opportunity is found in chaos, if you have the strength to seize it! \\n\\n You have found allies in the warlords before and there may yet be more to be found with the strongest of them. Yet any who oppose you, even the tyrant himself, must be crushed by the power of the Black Mountain bandits!

It is said, that Ashima, having been forbidden to marry her love, turned into a stone within the Stone Forest. This powerful symbol attracts many pilgrims to the grey walls of the forest, and the site itself contains a strange power...

My Lord, I bring terrible news! Your son, Liu Mao, who had long been shackled by debilitating illness, has unfortunately passed. It is with great grief that I tell you this, as I am sure the loss will weigh heavily on your mind.

The weight of your decision looms heavy. Some would call you a traitor to your own, but the decision was not theirs to make. These are the dilemmas that only an emperor can answer.\\n\\nThere are those who may have lost faith in your decisions, others may seek to use the opportunity to weaken and replace you. Now is not the time for indecision; deal with the fallout swiftly.

This administrator’s talents lie in bureaucracy, and they have organised the building of a new local irrigation system. The crop yield is improved with the regular and increased application of diverted water, and the people are happy to be governed by someone who is concerned with improving the area.
The people of Jiaozhi remember the times before the Han dominance, and as such can often be found bearing stones near Ma Yuan's column; to some a sign of security, to others a mark of misfortune.
Five renowned warriors, their prowess supposedly unmatched. Until now.

You and your brother Yuan Shu have been spending more time together feasting and carousing. Over this time you have started to forget your differences and have reached a truly amicable relationship; to find brotherly love once again is a true joy.

Silence is, to some, its own kind of cacophony - the eruption of a vacuum that is intolerable. Yet to others, silence is the purest beauty there can be. \\n\\n Two warriors, finding they share a love of absence, become friends. Together, they while away the long hours in absolute peace.

Your spy reports that only good fortune prevented their mission from ending in tragedy rather than triumph. As their arrest was imminent, a horde of bandits raided the settlement, enabling the spy to escape among the confusion.

It is peculiar, you admit, to see two people renowned for arrogance getting along so well, but that is how it appears to be. The pair's friendship blooms, despite - or perhaps even because of - their almost blinding sense of self-importance. \\n\\n You wonder how long it can last, but wish it longevity nevertheless.

Dian Wei, known as a bastion of strength and loyalty. It is said that once, a mighty banner was blowing over in the breeze and ten men could not hold it up. However, Dian Wei, using just one hand, held that banner upright earning great fame.

An unmistakable scent drifts over the battlements. Every troop in your army recoils in disgust, but they too know the omen - disease has struck the enemy! Beyond the gates, they writhe in agony as pestilence takes hold. This could work to our advantage!

While travelling along a secluded lane, your general notices a beam of coloured light rising from a well. They order their troops to light torches and descend the well to investigate, believing it to be a beckoning sign from heaven.

Liu Zhang grows wary of threats from warlords across China. Word reaches you from his messenger that he has noticed your exploits, and may seek an audience with you soon. "For now," explains the messenger, "know that my lord thinks you a shining beacon upon an ocean of despair."

Your general draws your attention to the unseasonal frost that paints the lands white. They say this is a sign that change is coming sooner than expected, and you can expect your fortunes to soon improve.

Ahuinan is a great warrior, well respected by those who serve him. His martial prowess has been tested at many a tournament across the land, where he has demonstrated his considerable combat skills to great acclaim against local contenders.
The mighty warrior and hero Liu Chong has been slain by the coward Yuan Shu. It has been said that he employed assassins to kill the prince during the night.

The comfort of camp can leave the constant warrior bored and restless, so Wutugu leaves in the early hours of the morning. With the sun high in the midday sky, he is seen walking back into camp with a laden cart in tow. A great set of antlers along with several slain deer lie upon the wagon. Wutugu enthusiastically presents the kitchens with his bounty and welcomes the soldiers to join the feast. Fresh game is always a welcome pleasure for an army on the move.

The comfort of camp can leave the constant warrior bored and restless, so Wutugu leaves in the early hours of the morning. Late in the evening he is seen returning to camp, though it would appear he has come back empty handed, his escapade having been a fruitless one. Without a word to his men, he enters his tent. Though such a matter should be trivial, for a man such as Wutugu it could be a source of great frustration. Be sure that this one does not become too disheartened.

This general begs you to meet them in the nearby woods at dawn. Upon arriving, they point out two tall pines with conjoined branches. With a smile on their face, they tell you that this is a promise of reconciliation, and that you are on the right path to reunite China.

This administrator has a distinguished demeanour and inspires immediate respect wherever they go. Only recently, they were stopped in the street and offered a gift from a noble, no doubt hoping for the approval of one who appears to be on the road to greater things...

As the siege continues, you search for ways to expedite the process. Your forces cut off vital supply routes, leaving the defending forces behind the walls more and more isolated. Without aid, they will eventually succumb to hunger and disease. We need only wait.

The governance of Yi province has long been steeped in violent uprisings. Some say previous leaders were despots, taxing their people excessively and ruling unfairly, but others whisper that the new governor, Liu Yan, is even more troublesome – not for his cruelty, of which he has little, but for his ambition.

Yuan Shao greets you with a solemn bow. "I must leave. The chaos has grown too much for me to bear, and I shall raise my own blade in its defence. I pray that we do not become enemies, but these are turbulent times."

The work to ensure your heir is prepared for their future role is almost endless, and you labour tirelessly to ensure they live up to the demands your ambition makes of them. Today, you take a step closer towards that goal, as an aspiration task is now complete! Your heir will thank you when the time comes to inherit.

A Yellow Turban officer, Tang Zhou, has seen the error of his ways and surrendered to the emperor. He has implicated others in the plot, who have been swiftly dealt the Emperor's justice. It seems the Yellow Turbans are planning to strike against the Empire!
A faction has sought to spread rumours about you within the imperial court. Whether this rumour is beneficial or damaging to your favour with the emperor remains to be seen.
To prevent threats to your northern frontier, you form an alliance with the Wuhuan tribes of the north. In exchange for goods and gifts they agree to allow you access to some of their horses.
The emperor holds you in high regard. As a sign of his favour he has given you additional food supplies for a short time, to ensure the people are fed while you improve your infrastructure.
